topic:
tropical storms

What tropical storms (hurricanes and typhoons) have caused significant property damage and loss of life?  

The date of the storm, the area affected, and the extent of damage/casualties are all of interest.  Documents that describe the damage caused by a tropical storm as "slight", "limited", or "small" are not relevant.

results.content:
1999-08-24 23:40:11 
 usa 
 Hurricane Season in Full Swing 


	MIAMI (AP) -- The 1999 hurricane season was in full swing  
Tuesday, with three tropical storms swirling in the Atlantic Ocean. 


	Tropical Storm Emily joined Dennis and Cindy, taking forecasters  
by surprise with her strength. 


	``I don't understand what's happening out there, but things are  
popping,'' said Jerry Jarrell, director of the National Hurricane 
Center in Miami. 


	The government of the Bahamas issued a tropical storm warning  
Tuesday for the Turks and Caicos Islands and for the southeastern 
Bahamas. 


	Tropical Storm Dennis could threaten the eastern United States  
as early as Friday. At 2 a.m. Wednesday, Dennis was centered about 
75 miles north of the Caicos islands. 


	Some strengthening was forecast through Wednesday, and it was  
expected to become a hurricane in the next day or so, according to 
the hurricane center. 


	``We think Dennis will turn up the east coast and with any luck  
will miss everything, but it will come close enough where we'll 
worry about it,'' Jarrell said. ``In three days it can be on almost 
any of us.'' 


	Emily had 65 mph winds, just shy of hurricane strength, but  
those winds slowed down to 45 mph by late Tuesday. Forecasters had 
not even listed the storm as a depression before the tropical storm 
advisory Tuesday afternoon. 


	Meanwhile, far east in the Atlantic, Tropical Storm Cindy  
continued moving across the open ocean. 


	Up until this past week, there had only been one tropical storm,  
Arlene, in June. 


	A tropical storm carries winds of 39 to 73 mph. A tropical storm  
becomes a hurricane when sustained winds reach 74 mph.

results.content:
Tropical Storm Nicole strengthens in the Atlantic


	   MIAMI (AP) _ Tropical Storm Nicole restrengthened Friday, but
forecasters said the storm will not threaten land.
	   At 2200 GMT Friday, Nicole's center was near 25.7 latitude, 43.2
longitude, or about 1,570 miles (2,527 kilometers) west-southwest
of the Canary Islands of the African coast.
	   Nicole is moving west at about 12 mph (20 kph), the National
Hurricane Center said.
	   The storm has 45 mph (72 kph) winds with higher gusts. Tropical
storm force winds extend up to 105 miles (170 kilometers) for the
storm's center.
	   Nicole, the 14th named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season,
formed Tuesday and intensified quickly to near hurricane strength.
It weakened Thursday to a tropical depression and then became a low
pressure center before regaining strength.
	   An impending cold front is expected to sweep the storm away,
said hurricane specialist Miles Lawrence.
	   ``It's not threatening land, but not dissipating as fast as we
previously forecast,'' Lawrence said.
	   A tropical depression becomes a named tropical storm when it has
top sustained winds of 39 mph (63 kph). Tropical storms become
hurricanes as their top sustained winds reach 74 mph (119 kph).
	   The annual Atlantic basin hurricane season begins June 1 and
ends Nov. 30. Such a late-season storm was not unusual, hurricane
experts said.

results.content:
1999-10-19 08:40:32 
 usa 
 Tropical Storm Jose Strengthening 


	MIAMI (AP) -- With winds increasing to within 9 mph of being  
hurricane strength, Tropical Storm Jose marched Tuesday toward the 
Leeward Islands in the northeastern Caribbean, threatening to 
become a hurricane before nightfall. 


	``It's coming up in strength,'' said Jack Bevin, hurricane  
specialist at the National Hurricane Center in Miami. ``It could 
(become a hurricane) today, could be some time this afternoon.'' 


	At 8 a.m. EDT, the storm's center was near 14.0 north latitude  
and 58.0 west longitude, about 240 miles east-southeast of Dominica 
in the Leeward Islands of the Lesser Antilles. 


	``The Leeward Islands are the ones that are really in threat of  
being hit,'' said Michael Formosa, meteorologist at the Center. 


	A tropical storm warning was in effect for Barbados early  
Tuesday, while a hurricane watch was in effect for the Leeward 
Islands from Anguilla to Montserrat, and for St. Lucia in the 
Windward Islands. 


	St. Vincent and the Grenadines were under a tropical storm  
watch. 


	Puerto Rico and the U.S. and British Virgin Islands were urged  
to closely monitor the storm's progress. 


	Grenada was no longer under a tropical storm watch early  
Tuesday. 


	Jose was moving west-northwest near 13 mph and this motion was  
expected to continue for the next 24 hours. Maximum sustained winds 
were near 65 mph, with higher gusts. Tropical storm force winds 
extended outward up to 60 miles. 


	Tropical storms become hurricanes once their top sustained winds  
reach 74 mph. Jose is the 10th tropical storm of the 1999 season, 
which runs from June 1 through Nov. 30.

results.content:
HURRICANE WATCH IS ON FOR THE SUMMER 



   SAN FRANCISCO _ The retreat of El Nino should mean a calmer
overall hurricane season for Hawaii and the tropical Pacific, but
storm watchers warn the early part of the season could see a repeat
of last summer's violent tropical storms.


   Monday marked the beginning of the 1998 hurricane season in the
central Pacific. Hurricane season runs through Nov. 15 in the
eastern Pacific and through October in the central Pacific.


   Many scientists say the 1997-98 El Nino, an oceanwide warming of
the Pacific's surface temperatures, is waning. Nevertheless, this
El Nino, one of the biggest ever recorded, may still cause storm
trouble.


   The federal Climate Prediction Center forecasts above-normal
water temperatures in the equatorial eastern Pacific through
midsummer before approaching normal conditions by early fall.


   ``Based on this forecast, there may be a tendency to have an
increase in the number of tropical cyclones during the early part
of the hurricane season,'' said Jim Weyman, director of the Central
Pacific Hurricane Center.


   But he admits there is no certainty.


   ``The formation, growth, movement and dissipation of tropical
cyclones are governed by many complex factors, only one of which is
warm ocean water,'' Weyman said.


   During last summer's hurricane season, when El Nino was
developing, there were nine major tropical storm systems in the
central Pacific, twice the 36-year average and the fourth highest
number of tropical storms during that period.


   While full-blown hurricanes are rare in Hawaii _ there have been
only four this century _ they are devastating when they do hit.


   On Sept. 11, 1992, Hurricane Iniki caused $1.8 billion in losses
on Kauai.


   ``Regardless of the number of hurricanes and tropical storms
that may occur, every citizen of Hawaii should prepare for a
hurricane or tropical storm because it only takes one to cause
extreme devastation,'' Weyman told a briefing at the University of
Hawaii at Manoa last week.


   Hurricanes are more common in the eastern Pacific, with the
ocean west of Mexico acting as a breeding ground for the big
storms.


   In a typical year, 16 or 17 tropical storms and nine hurricanes
form off the west coast of Mexico, some of them moving ashore with
disastrous results.


   The record-breaking storm season for the eastern Pacific was a
non-El Nino year, 1992, when 27 tropical cyclones rampaged around
the ocean.


   Unlike the hit-and-run Iniki, some hurricanes can hang around
for a long time. A 1994 storm named John formed off Mexico on Aug.
11, traveled more than 4,000 miles over 31 days and reached peak
winds of 170 mph.


   Because John crossed the international dateline twice during its
raucous journey, it changed status from hurricane to typhoon and
back to hurricane. In the Atlantic and eastern Pacific east of the
dateline, storms attaining sustained winds of 74 mph or higher are
hurricanes; the same tropical cyclone west of the international
dateline is called a typhoon.


   A tropical depression, which is far more common than its bigger
and nastier cousins, is an organized cluster of thunderstorms with
sustained winds below 38 mph; a tropical storm is more organized,
with winds between 39 and 73 mph.

results.content:
Depression becomes Tropical Storm Bonnie


	   MIAMI (AP) _ A tropical depression moving toward the Caribbean
became Tropical Storm Bonnie on Thursday afternoon, and forecasters
expected it to reach hurricane status by the weekend.
	   ``We have the system going to hurricane strength by 48 hours,
and by 72 hours we have the system up to about 85 mph (136 kph) ,''
said John Guiney, hurricane specialist at the National Hurricane
Center.
	   At 5 p.m. EDT, Bonnie was centered near 17.8 north latitude,
60.7 west longitude, about 75 miles east of the northern Leeward
Islands of the eastern Caribbean. The storm was headed
west-northwest near 25 mph (40 kph) with top winds of 50 mph (80
kph).
	   Forecasters expected Bonnie to hold that course and slow
somewhat. Tropical storm force winds extended 115 miles from the
storm's center.
	   A tropical storm warning was issued Thursday evening for the
U.S. and British Virgin Islands. A tropical storm watch remained in
effect for the northern Leeward Islands of Antigua, Barbuda,
Anguilla, St. Maarten, Saba, St. Eustatius and Puerto Rico.
	   By Thursday evening, Bonnie's rainbands and gusty winds were
spreading over the Leeward Islands as well as the British and U.S.
Virgin Islands.
	   Tropical systems become named storms when their top sustained
winds reach 39 mph (62 kph). The hurricane threshold is 74 mph (118
kph).
	   The Atlantic hurricane season began in June and ends in
November.
	   The season's first, Tropical Storm Alex, fizzled out before it
reached the Caribbean earlier this month.

results.content:
1999-08-10 20:20:01 
 usa 
 Busy Hurricane Season Predicted 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- People shouldn't be fooled by this year's slow  
start to hurricane season, government scientists say. With the peak 
period about to begin, meteorologists are predicting more storms 
than usual. 


	Scientists say three or more intense Atlantic storms are  
possible, and residents living along the East and Gulf coasts 
should remain prepared. 


	Last year's hurricane season produced 14 tropical storms,  
including three major hurricanes. In a typical season, the United 
States experiences five to six hurricanes, two of which are severe 
and an average of 1.5 storms make landfall. 


	``Just because we haven't seen a hurricane yet this year, don't  
get fooled into thinking that this will be a light season'', said 
Gerald Bell, a research meteorologist at National Oceanic and 
Atmospheric Administration's Climate Prediction Center. 


	Hurricane season officially runs from June 1 to Nov. 30, but  
tropical storms don't really rev up until mid-August. The peak 
period runs from mid-August to mid-October. 


	The season is expected to be busy due to atmospheric conditions  
globally that contribute to hurricanes, said CPC meteorologist 
Vernon Kousky. Among those conditions are a low wind shear across 
the tropical Atlantic and below-average air pressure across the 
tropical Atlantic Ocean and Caribbean Sea. 


	``The odds are tilted in the favor of more storms than normal,''  
said Kousky. 


	Hurricane expert William Gray of Colorado State University has  
gone a step further, predicting 14 named tropical storms, nine 
hurricanes and four intense hurricanes. Gray figures there is a 54 
percent chance that one or more intense storms with wind speeds of 
111 miles per hour or more will hit the East Coast and a 40 percent 
chance for the Gulf Coast. 


	So far this season, there has been one tropical storm, Arlene,  
in June. 


	A tropical storm carries winds of 39 to 73 mph. A tropical storm  
becomes a hurricane when sustained winds reach 74 mph.

results.content:
Tropical Storm Celia strengthening off Mexico's Pacific coast


	   MEXICO CITY (AP) _ A new tropical storm gaining strength off
Mexico's Pacific coast could bring tropical storm force winds to
Baja California on Saturday, forecasters said.
	   On Friday night, the center of Tropical Storm Celia was 250
miles (400 kilometers) south-southeast of the southern tip of Baja
California, the peninsula that juts south from California, the U.S.
Hurricane Center reported from Miami.
	   Celia was moving northwest at 14 mph (22 kph). Forecasters said
it would be 125 miles (200 kilometers) off the tip of Baja
California on Saturday. Tropical storm force winds extended outward
from the center up to 105 miles (170 kilometers), and the storm was
strengthening.
	   Maximum sustained winds were near 55 mph (88 kph). A tropical
storm becomes a hurricane when its sustained winds top 74 mph (119
kph).
	   Maritime authorities closed the port of Acapulco to fishing and
recreation boats Thursday. Larger vessels were urged to sail with
caution, the government news agency Notimex said.

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-05-22 16:21 
 Tropical Storm Forms Off Acapulco  


   MEXICO CITY (AP) -- The first tropical depression of the year
formed Monday in the Pacific off the coast of Acapulco, but was not
expected to hit land.


   The depression, with winds gusting at about 35 mph, was expected
to move west-northwest over the next few days and to stay away from
the Mexican coast, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center
in Miami.


   The depression was forecast to strengthen, though, in which case
it could take a more northerly track toward the coast, possibly
becoming a tropical storm later Monday.


   Storms are classified as tropical depressions when their winds
are below 39 mph, tropical storms when the winds range from 39 to
73 mph, and hurricanes when the winds exceed 73 mph.


   Monday's tropical depression marked the first storm of the
eastern Pacific hurricane season, which officially begins June 1.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has predicted
11 tropical storms this year, seven of which will be hurricanes,
three of them major.


   The La Nina cooling of water in the Pacific Ocean -- the same
condition that influenced the 1999 season -- remains in place this
year, officials said.


 AP-NY-05-22-00 1621

results.content:
Tropical storm watches posted for some of the Leeward Islands


	   MIAMI (AP) _ A tropical depression moving across the Atlantic
Ocean northeastward of the Lesser Antilles was expected to become a
tropical storm late Thursday, forecasters said.
	   Tropical storm watches were in effect for Antigua, Barbuda,
Anguilla, St. Maarten, Saba and St. Eustatius, but the main part of
the system was expected to pass offshore.
	   Outer rainbands of the depression began spreading over portions
of the Leewards during the morning, accompanied by locally heavy
showers and some squalls.
	   The weather system had steady winds of 35 mph (56 kph) at 11
a.m. EDT Thursday and was located about 250 miles (400 kilometers)
east-northeast of the Leeward Islands, moving west-northwest at
about 23 mph (37 kph).
	   The depression will become Tropical Storm Bonnie if it reaches
steady winds of 39 mph (62 kph). It would be the second tropical
storm of the season.
	   The system's track would likely put it east of the Bahamas by
the weekend, forecasters said.
	   The National Hurricane Center planned to send out a plane early
Thursday afternoon to study the depression.
	   Forecasters are also watching four other tropical waves, or low
pressure systems, that rose up earlier this week.
	   The Atlantic hurricane season began in June and ends in
November.
	   The season's first, Tropical Storm Alex, fizzled out before it
reached the Caribbean earlier this month.

results.content:
Mexico issues tropical storm warning for strengthening Celia


	   MEXICO CITY (AP) _ Mexico issued a tropical storm warning for
southern Baja California Friday night as Tropical Storm Celia
picked up strength and swirled toward the area.
	   Forecasters expected winds of tropical storm force for southern
Baja California, the peninsula that juts south from the U.S. state
of California, by Saturday, the U.S. Hurricane Center reported from
Miami.
	   Late Friday night, the center of Celia was located 225 miles
(360 kilometers) south-southeast of Cabo San Lucas, a beach and
fishing resort on the tip of Baja California.
	   The storm was moving northwest at about 16 mph (26 kph) and was
expected to continue at that speed and direction. If it did,
Celia's center would be about 100 miles (160 kilometers) from the
tip of the peninsula on Saturday.
	   Maximum sustained winds were near 60 mph (97 kph). A tropical
storm becomes a hurricane when sustained winds exceed 73 mph (117
kph), and forecasters expected Celia to strengthen.
	   Mexico issued tropical storm warnings for the southern portion
of Baja California from the port of La Paz southward.

1999-09-10 03:20:14 
 usa 
 Tropical Storm Floyd Gains Strength 


	MIAMI (AP) -- With forecasts predicting Tropical Storm Floyd  
would become a hurricane, the storm moved closer to the Caribbean, 
where some governments had already issued tropical storm watches. 


	``We think it will probably strengthen into a hurricane later  
today,'' said Richard Pasch, hurricane specialist with the National 
Hurricane Center in Miami. ``Conditions are favorable for it to 
strengthen and it's very close to a hurricane already.'' 


	By early today, Floyd had top sustained winds of 70 mph, just 4  
mph shy of hurricane strength, and was expected to increase in 
strength. 


	Floyd, the sixth tropical storm of the season, was centered  
about 215 miles east-northeast of Barbuda in the northern Leeward 
Islands. It was expected to continue moving toward the 
west-northwest at near 12 mph. 


	The storm was expected to pass just north of the Leeward  
Islands, but could threaten the northeastern Caribbean if it were 
to shift at all to the south, said hurricane specialist Lixion 
Avila. 


	The island governments of Antigua, Barbuda, Anguilla and Dutch  
Saint Maarten, French St. Martin, and St. Barthelemy all had issued 
tropical storm watches. 


	``Right now the focus is on the Leeward Islands,'' Franklin  
said. ``Any potential threat to the U.S. would be several days down 
the road.'' 


	Tropical storm force winds extended outward up to 175 miles from  
the storm's center, which at 5 a.m. was located at 18.9 north 
latitude, 58.7 west longitude.

NEWS STORY 
 2000-09-02 19:31 
 Tropical Storm Ernesto forms deep in Atlantic, poses no threat  


	   MIAMI (AP) - Tropical Storm Ernesto, the fifth named storm of
the 2000 hurricane season, formed early Saturday deep in the
Atlantic Ocean but posed no immediate threat to land, a
meteorologist said.


   ''It's a minimal tropical storm,'' said Eric Blake of the
National Hurricane Center in Miami. ''It's no threat.''


   Ernesto originated from a tropical wave in the Atlantic. At 5
p.m. EDT, the storm was located about 600 miles east of the Leeward
Islands - at 17.8 north latitude, 52.7 west longitude. That's about
1,800 miles east-southeast of the Florida coast.


   The storm's top sustained winds were near 40 mph and tropical
storm force winds were extending 115 miles from its center. Ernesto
was moving west-northwest at 15 mph.


   ''At this time through (Monday) we expect it to remain over the
open ocean,'' Blake said.

 usa 
 Tropical Storm Forms in Atlantic 


	MIAMI (AP) -- Tropical Storm Floyd, the sixth named storm this  
season, formed in the Atlantic early today with ominous potential, 
hurricane forecasters said. 


	The storm, with winds near 40 mph, was about 755 miles east of  
the Leeward Islands moving west-northwest at nearly 16 mph, 
according to the National Hurricane Center in suburban Miami. 


	Tropical storm force winds extended up to 85 miles from the  
center of the storm. 


	Floyd was expected to strengthen while continuing at the same  
speed through early Thursday, moving well northeast of Puerto Rico 
and the Leeward Islands in the northeastern Caribbean islands. 


	It was expected to be a hurricane by late Thursday.  


	``Floyd is a good candidate to ultimately achieve major  
hurricane status,'' forecaster Richard Pasch said. 


	Floyd formed from a brief tropical depression that came from a  
disturbance working its way west across the southern North 
Atlantic. 


	Tropical depressions become named storms if their sustained  
circulating winds reach 39 mph. They become hurricanes if the winds 
hit 74 mph.

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-09-30 18:08 
 Tropical Storm Keith Strengthens  


   MEXICO CITY (AP) -- Tropical Storm Keith strengthened to a
hurricane Saturday and threatened to hit Mexico's Yucatan
peninsula.


   Heavy rain pounded the eastern Yucatan, Belize and northern
Honduras on Saturday. Storm surges caused rivers to overflow and
flooded thousands of homes, civil protection officials in Mexico
said.


   A hurricane warning remained in effect along the Yucatan
peninsula's eastern shore, from Cabo Catoche south to Monkey River
Town in Belize, according to the National Hurricane Center in
Miami.


   At 4 p.m. EDT, Keith was centered about about 105 miles
east-southeast of Chetumal, Mexico. Maximum sustained winds
increased to 100 mph, and forecasters expected the storm to drift
north-northwest Sunday.


   A tropical storm becomes a hurricane when winds reach 74 mph.


   Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Joyce headed for the Windward Islands,
raising storm warnings for Trinidad, Tobago and Grenada. A tropical
storm watch was in effect for Barbados, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and
the Grenadines.


   Hurricane Isaac diminished Saturday, with sustained winds at
about 75 mph. The storm was in open water, about 1,120 miles west
of the westernmost Azores.


   ------

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-08-16 00:05 
 Tropical Storm Churns Past Baja  
By MARK STEVENSON


   MEXICO CITY (AP) -- Tropical Storm Ileana churned past the
southern tip of the Baja California peninsula Tuesday and headed
out to sea, while Tropical Storm Beryl moved inland, dumping rain
on Texas and northern Mexico as it weakened.


   Ileana doused the Baja resort towns of Los Cabos with rain, but
''nothing too severe,'' said Randy Lehr, the American manager of
the Hacienda Beach Resort in Cabo San Lucas.


   ''It looks like we got lucky, and the storm passed by to the
south,'' Lehr said in telephone interview. Guests at his hotel were
warned to stay out of the ocean, and some whiled away the time
playing pool.


   The Mexican government discontinued a hurricane warning for Los
Cabos and areas slightly north after the storm's center whirled
past 50 miles south of the peninsula.


   ''There hasn't been any damage so far, and the communications
systems are working fine,'' said Baja California state spokesman
Juan Antonio Flores.


   The storm, with winds of 70 mph, was churning out to sea at 10
mph.


   Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Beryl lumbered ashore on Mexico's
northeast coast Tuesday, swirling into land over a sparsely
populated stretch of coast 110 miles south of the border cities of
Matamoros and Brownsville.


   The storm quickly weakened to tropical depression status as it
dropped rain over northern Mexico, and the Mexican government
discontinued most storm warnings for coastal areas.


   The hurricane center reported Beryl could cause rainfall of 5 to
10 inches, but predicted the system would probably dissipate by
Wednesday.


   Beryl's winds had fallen to 35 mph, and the weakening system was
moving roughly west at about 9 mph.


   Authorities in the Mexican border state of Nuevo Leon evacuated
about 1,500 people from low-lying areas near river beds Tuesday as
the remnants of tropical storm Beryl approached the state capitol
of Monterrey.


   State civil defense officials said the evacuees would probably
be able to return to their homes after a few hours, when the danger
of flash flooding had decreased, the government news agency Notimex
reported.


   It rained intermittently Tuesday in Monterrey. The city is
vulnerable to flash flooding because of insufficient storm drains.


   The U.S. National Weather Service canceled hurricane and
tropical storm warnings for South Texas, where some heavy showers
were reported.


 AP-NY-08-16-00 0005

WEATHER 



   NATIONAL FORECAST &QL;


   At daybreak Saturday, temperatures fell into the 40s in parts of
the Northeast as a cool air mass from Canada poured into the
region. Another cool morning is expected Sunday across the
Northeast before warmer and more humid air arrives Monday.


   High pressure drifting off the coast will provide New England
with plentiful sunshine, raising temperatures to seasonal levels by
Sunday afternoon. Farther west, a cluster of thunderstorms, on the
leading edge of sultry air, will affect Michigan and Ohio early
Sunday. The inclement weather will reach the Appalachians by the
afternoon.


   Strong afternoon thunderstorms will erupt in the western Great
Lakes and Ohio Valley. As the storms circulate speedy air aloft to
the surface, damaging winds will occur in some spots.


   Most of the West will be seasonably hot. Isolated thunderstorms
will form near the high peaks of the Rockies.  &QL;


   FOCUS: FIRST STORM


   The Atlantic hurricane season began a little later than usual
this year when Tropical Storm Alberto was christened near the Cape
Verde Islands off West Africa on Aug. 4. In 70 percent of the years
on record at least one tropical storm has formed by Aug. 1.
Tropical Storm Alberto which is still churning through the tropical
Atlantic took shape at 25 degrees west longitude. It now holds the
distinction of forming farther east than any tropical storm this
early in the season. Cool water near the west coast of Africa often
interferes with tropical storm development in that region. &QL;

results.content:
HURRICANES _ FROM ARLENE TO ZELDA 
 FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE 
 FROM THE FORT WORTH STAR-TELEGRAM



   What is a hurricane?


   A hurricane is an intense tropical storm that has winds of 74
mph and higher, according to the National Hurricane Center.


   These winds blow in a large spiral around a calm center, called
the ``eye.'' The eye is 20-30 miles wide. In the Northern
Hemisphere of the Earth, winds move counterclockwise around the
eye. In the Southern Hemisphere, winds circulate clockwise.


   Hurricanes develop over tropical ocean waters and many remain
there. When a hurricane does approach land, skies begin to darken
and winds strengthen. The hurricane begins driving water ahead of
it in a storm surge or tidal wave that can be 20 feet at its peak.
Hurricanes can also trigger tornadoes and floods.


   How are hurricanes named?


   The World Meteorological Organization has chosen an alphabetical
list of names for tropical storms and hurricanes, and the list
rotates every six years. That practice started in 1953. Names used
for storms this year are the same that were used in 1993.


   The names of tropical storms and hurricanes used to be all
women's names until 1978 and '79. Now, men's names are alternated
with women's.


   Sometimes, when a hurricane is particularly destructive, the
name is retired, which means the name can't be used for at least 10
years.


   One such name was Hurricane Andrew, which struck Florida and
Louisiana in 1992. The storm caused 54 deaths and up to $30 billion
in damage.


   To put that in context, the Galveston, Texas hurricane of 1900
(before hurricanes were named) caused 6,000 deaths, the most in
U.S. history, according to the World Almanac and Book of Facts.


   Where and when are most hurricanes in the United States?


   Florida has the most hurricanes in the United States, the
National Hurricane Center reports.


   Other places vulnerable to hurricanes are the coasts along the
Gulf of Mexico and the North Atlantic Ocean, from Texas to Maine.


   The hurricane season is from June 1 to Nov. 30, and peak months
are August and September.


   Which hurricanes and tropical storms have formed in the Atlantic
Ocean this year?


   Arlene: This tropical storm formed on June 11 and spent its life
at sea in the central Atlantic. Winds reached 65 mph.


   Bret: This hurricane struck the Texas coast near Corpus Christi
and Brownsville on Aug. 22. It had winds of 125 mph.


   Cindy: This hurricane formed near the Cape Verde Islands west of
the African country of Senegal but did not come ashore. On Aug. 28,
it reached its peak intensity of 140 mph.


   Dennis: This storm formed on Aug. 23, became a hurricane on Aug.
26 and reached 105 mph on Aug. 28. It moved up the southeast U.S.
coast and struck the North Carolina coast on Aug. 30.


   Emily: This tropical storm formed on Aug. 24 and reached wind
speeds of 65 mph.


   Floyd: This storm was upgraded to a hurricane on Sept. 10,
reaching peak winds of 155 mph. Blowing from the Bahamas to the
Carolinas to New England, it caused 60 deaths, immense flooding of
roads and buildings, and mass road closures and power outages. Walt
Disney World was closed for bad weather for the first time in its
history.


   Gert: Winds from this storm reached 130 to 145 mph on Sept. 17
and caused damage to structures and beaches in Bermuda. The
hurricane weakened to a tropical storm on Sept. 23.


   Harvey: This tropical storm formed in the Gulf of Mexico on
Sept. 19 and dumped 10 inches of rain on south Florida.


   What are this year's names for hurricanes?


   Here's the list of names for hurricanes and tropical storms that
have occurred or might develop in the North Atlantic Ocean, Gulf of
Mexico and Caribbean Sea:


   Arlene, Bret, Cindy, Dennis, Emily, Floyd, Gert, Harvey, Irene,
Jose, Katrina, Lenny, Maria, Nate, Ophelia, Philipe, Rita, Stan,
Tammy, Vince and Wilma.


   Here are the names for those in the eastern Pacific Ocean:


   Adrian, Beatriz, Calvin, Dora, Eugene, Fernanda, Greg, Hilary,
Irwin, Joba, Kenneth, Lidia, Max, Otis, Pilar

results.content:
WEATHER 



   NATIONAL FORECAST


   On Thursday the ill-defined center of stagnant Tropical Storm
Frances wobbled over the Gulf of Mexico about 150 miles east of
Brownsville, Texas. Friday, the sluggish system will likely
approach southern Texas. A storm surge of several feet will
continue as the tropical storm comes ashore, causing additional
flooding. Heavy rains will affect much of the Texas seaboard as
robust onshore winds transport moisture inland. Because of the
broad and complex nature of the system, a second focus of heavy
rain could occur over parts of Louisiana and Mississippi, rather
far removed from the storm's center. Cirrus clouds blowing east of
the top of the system will dim the sun as far east as Georgia.


   Scattered showers and thunderstorms will flare over the
Southwestern states as a nearly stationary low pressure system at
altitudes of several thousand feet over the central Sierra Nevada
continues to draw moisture northward. Farther northeast, scattered
showers and isolated storms will develop over parts of the northern
Rockies in response to a jet stream disturbance.


   Meanwhile, the leading edge of warmer air will push toward the
Northeast on Friday. After a chilly start, temperatures will rise
toward seasonal levels, but variable cirrus clouds will limit
warming in some places, particularly over the northern Middle
Atlantic and eastern Great Lakes states.


   Isolated showers will escort a cool front across the upper
Middle West. With steering winds blowing from the west, the coolest
air in the wake of the front will be confined to Canada.


   FOCUS: HURRICANE APEX


   Tropical Storm Frances formed over the Gulf of Mexico on
Wednesday, and the system will continue to batter the Texas coast
Friday at the apex of the tropical storm season. In nine out of ten
years since 1886, at least one tropical storm or hurricane has
raged in the Atlantic on September 11. No other date has had more
storms. Atlantic waters are warmest in early September, nurturing
tropical storms, which draw energy from the warmth of the ocean.
Meanwhile, strong high-level winds associated with the jet stream
that are capable of tearing a storm apart are normally still over
northern latitudes.

 Tropical Storm Floyd Gains Strength 


	MIAMI (AP) -- Tropical Storm Floyd whirled in the Atlantic at  
near-hurricane strength Thursday, putting several Caribbean 
countries on alert. 


	Forecasters with the National Hurricane Center said that if the  
storm were to threaten the East Coast of the United States, it 
would not be for several days. 


	Floyd, the sixth tropical storm of the season, had sustained  
winds increasing to nearly 70 mph, just 4 mph shy of hurricane 
strength. Forecaster James Franklin said Floyd probably would 
become a hurricane by Friday afternoon. 


	At 11 p.m. EDT, the storm was centered about 265 miles east of  
Barbuda in the Leeward Islands. It moved slowly westward through 
much of the evening, but was forecast to resume its earlier 
west-northwest course, at about 10 mph, early Friday. 


	The storm was expected to pass to the north of the Leeward  
Islands, but it could threaten the northeastern Caribbean if it 
shifts to the south. The governments of Antigua, Barbuda, Anguilla, 
St. Martin, and St. Barthelemy issued tropical storm watches.

results.content:
BEFORE THE STORM COMES THE CALM 



   SARASOTA, Fla. _ Hey, Gert, Jose and Katrina, where are you?


   Despite predictions of a busy hurricane season, it's been a
fizzle so far. So the question is: Were the forecasters way off?


   Their advice: Don't start digging into the canned tuna in your
hurricane supplies just yet.


   ``Two words: last year,'' said hurricane forecaster Jack Beven
of the National Hurricane Center in Miami. ``Last year this time,
Alex, our first tropical storm, was forming. And later on we had 10
storms in 33 days.''


   Colorado State University professor Bill Gray predicted at the
start of the June-through-November hurricane season that 1999 might
be a repeat of last year, which produced a bumper crop of violent
storms.


   There were 14 tropical storms in 1998, 10 of which intensified
into hurricanes.


   Gray and his research team said in June that conditions were
right for 14 storms this season. If he's right _ and he often is _
we'll be closely watching storms named Gert, Jose, Katrina and many
more.


   But so far there's only been tropical storm Arlene, which
bypassed Bermuda in mid-June.


   Chris Landsea, a hurricane researcher for the National Oceanic
and Atmospheric Association and a former student of Gray's, says
the slow start to this year's hurricane season isn't unusual.


   ``The historical average is one and a half tropical storms
forming by Aug. 1, so it's pretty close to average,'' he said last
week.


   He said a slow start doesn't indicate that the season will be an
inactive one.


   In 1984 and 1988, the first hurricane didn't form until
September. Diana and Debby were the fourth tropical storms in those
years, but the first ones that developed hurricane-force winds of
at least 74 mph. Both 1984 and 1988 produced 12 tropical storms,
five of which became hurricanes.


   Nine tropical storms develop in an average year, with six of
them becoming hurricanes.


   ``If anything, the slow start of the storms forming in the
subtropics is a sign that it could be busier than usual later on,''
Landsea said.


   ``It would be nice if the ones that form in the subtropics were
forming more regularly, but they're not. It's another sign that
later on, the Cape Verde season could be a nasty one in 1999.''


   Storms referred to as Cape Verde storms develop near the Cape
Verde islands off the west coast of Africa and often become the
biggest and fiercest storms of the hurricane season as they gain
strength sweeping across the Atlantic. They can scour the Caribbean
islands, strike the United States or Mexican mainland, or curve
harmlessly into the North Atlantic.


   Hurricane activity peaks in mid-September. August, September and
October are the three most active months, with 90 percent of all
storms occurring in those months, Landsea said.


   Gray will update his forecast Friday, and the NOAA plans to
reassess the hurricane season next Monday.


   But Landsea said he sees no obvious reasons to scrap the
forecast for an active season that he and Gray predicted. Beven,
with the National Hurricane Center, agrees that conditions still
appear favorable for an above-normal hurricane season.


   A key factor is La Nina, the abnormal cooling of water in
equatorial Pacific waters. La Nina is expected to promote hurricane
development through the remainder of the year. Another factor Gray
takes into account is a high-pressure ridge in the North Atlantic,
which also promotes hurricane formation.


   (The Herald-Tribune in Sarasota, Fla., is part of the New York
Times Regional Newspaper Group.)

 Tropical Storm Jose Strengthening 


	MIAMI (AP) -- A weather system brewing in the Atlantic became  
Tropical Storm Jose early today and was expected to strengthen into 
a hurricane in the next few days, forecasters said. 


	``In 24 to 48 hours it could reach hurricane status,'' said Jack  
Bevin, a hurricane specialist at the National Hurricane Center in 
Miami. 


	Barbados was under a hurricane watch today. Forecasters said a  
similar watch could be issued for portions of the Windward Islands, 
an island chain in the southeastern Caribbean, later in the day. 


	In Trinidad and Tobago, residents were preparing for possible  
flooding. 


	At 8 a.m. EDT, the center of Tropical Storm Jose was about 430

	Jose was moving west near 10 mph and a gradual turn toward the  
west-northwest was expected. Maximum sustained winds were near 40 
mph, with higher gusts. The storm's tropical force winds extended 
outward up to 50 miles. 


	Jose is the 10th tropical storm of the 1999 Atlantic hurricane  
season, which runs from June 1 through Nov. 30.

1999-08-24 11:20:25 
 usa 
 Tropical Storm Could Affect E.Coast 


	MIAMI (AP) -- Tropical Storm Dennis formed today in the western  
Atlantic and was on a track that could affect the East Coast this 
weekend, forecasters said. 


	Dennis grew out of a tropical depression southeast of the  
Bahamas and north of Puerto Rico, becoming a named storm when its 
sustained wind speed topped 39 mph. 


	By 2 p.m. EDT today, it was centered about 85 miles north of  
Grand Turk in the Turks and Caicos Islands, the National Hurricane 
Center said. Grand Turk is 575 miles southeast of Miami. Dennis had 
wind blowing at a sustained 45 mph and was moving west-northwest at 
nearly 9 mph. 


	The government of the Bahamas issued a tropical storm warning  
for the Turks and Caicos Islands and the southeastern Bahamas. 


	The storm could be three days away from threatening the eastern  
United States, primarily the area from northern Florida to the 
Carolinas, said Jerry Jarrell, director of the hurricane center. 


	``But this could be one of those that goes up the whole East  
Coast and threatens everybody on the way and makes us all button 
up,'' he cautioned. 


	There was also a chance that Dennis could veer northward and  
away from the United States, forecasters said. 


	The hurricane center also was monitoring another tropical  
weather system located about 500 miles west of the Caribbean's 
Windward Islands. 


	``It is pretty well-organized,'' said forecaster Todd  
Kimberlain. 


	And in the mid Atlantic, Tropical Storm Cindy was centered about  
1,290 miles east of the Lesser Antilles. Cindy was traveling 
west-northwest at about 15 mph, with sustained wind near 60 mph.

NEWS STORY 
 2000-09-25 23:37 
 Isaac's top winds drop to 105 mph; tropical storm forms  


	   MIAMI (AP) - Hurricane Isaac remained deep in the Atlantic Ocean
and posed no immediate threat to land as its winds decreased to 105
mph Monday, forecasters said. Farther away, Tropical Storm Joyce
was born off West Africa.


   Isaac began losing power Sunday and that drop continued into
Monday, according to forecasters at the National Hurricane Center
in Miami.


   At 11 p.m. EDT, Isaac was about 1,280 miles east of the northern
Leeward Islands, at the eastern edge of the Caribbean, and moving
to the west-northwest at near 9 mph.


   ''It's very far from land and in three days it's still going to
be very far away from the islands,'' said hurricane specialist
James Franklin. ''If it continues on its present track, it would
pass well north of the islands.''


   Isaac became a tropical storm Thursday and quickly built into a
strong hurricane with winds of 120 mph by Saturday. But other
weather systems began affecting it, and its maximum sustained winds
dropped to 105 mph Monday.


   Satellite photographs showed that its once well-defined eye had
dropped from sight then reappeared less-defined, said hurricane
specialist Richard Pasch.


   Meanwhile, a growing system in the far eastern Atlantic
developed Monday from a weak tropical wave to a tropical
depression, then became Tropical Storm Joyce late in the evening.


   At 11 p.m. EDT, Joyce was centered near 11.7 north latitude,
32.6 west longitude, or about 570 miles west-southwest of the
southwestern Cape Verde islands.


   It was heading west at near 15 mph, with top sustained winds of
40 mph, just 1 mph over the threshold at which a tropical
depression becomes a named tropical storm.


   Joyce was expected to hold its course and forward speed through
much of Tuesday, while possibly getting stronger, forecasters said.
Tropical storms become hurricanes when their top winds reach 74
mph.


   ''It also is no immediate threat to any land,'' said hurricane
specialist Jack Beven.

1999-08-25 10:20:22 
 usa 
 Tropical Storm Heads Toward U.S. 


	MIAMI (AP) -- A hurricane watch was posted today for the Bahamas  
because of Tropical Storm Dennis and forecasters warned that the 
storm could affect the southeastern United States this weekend. 


	Dennis, one of three storm systems in the Atlantic, was 335  
miles east-southeast of Nassau, Bahamas, at 11 a.m. EDT with top 
wind of nearly 45 mph. 


	It was nearly stalled but was expected to resume a  
west-northwesterly track at about 8 mph some time today. 


	``The currents, the flow of air that would move it around have  
slacked off and nothing's pushing it yet,'' said hurricane 
specialist Stephen Baig. 


	Dennis was expected to strengthen and the central Bahamas were  
under a tropical storm warning. The hurricane watch covered the 
Turks, Caicos and other Bahama islands -- including Bimini, just 55 
miles from Florida. 


	``It's looking like it's going to be in the central Bahamas by  
Thursday,'' said Trisha Wallace, a meteorologist at the National 
Hurricane Center in Miami. 


	Tropical storm force wind of at least 39 mph extended up to 70  
miles from its center today. 


	``Residents along the entire southeastern United States coast  
should closely monitor the progress of this system,'' said 
hurricane specialist Jack Beven of the hurricane center. 


	Emily sprang up in the Caribbean on Tuesday, surprising  
forecasters who hadn't thought it was even a tropical depression. 


	At 11 a.m. EDT, Emily was 305 miles east of the Windward  
Islands, the southern Lesser Antilles, and was moving northwesterly 
at about 6 mph. It also had top wind of 45 mph, with little change 
expected before Thursday. 


	The storm was moving to the northwest at 6 mph and could tangle  
with Tropical Storm Cindy, which was farther out in the Atlantic. 


	``Emily could dissipate and essentially be sucked up into  
Cindy,'' Wallace said. ``It could also be the other way around.'' 


	She said a combined storm would not necessarily be twice as  
powerful. Beven said Emily could reach hurricane strength by 
Friday, if it stays far enough away from Cindy. 


	At 11 a.m. EDT, Cindy was about 1,130 miles east of the Leeward  
Islands. It was traveling west-northwest at 15 mph with top wind of 
65 mph. 


	Cindy was forecast to swing gradually north and stay over the  
open ocean.

Tropical storm strengethens off Mexico's Pacific coast


	   MEXICO CITY (AP) _ A tropical storm that formed off of Mexico's
Pacific coast is expected to become a hurricane but was heading
west and away from land, the U.S. National Hurricane Center
reported.
	   Tropical storm Estelle was over 300 miles (483 kilometers) south
of Manzanillo, Mexico at 11:00 a.m. EDT (1500 GMT), with sustained
winds of nearly 70 mph (113 kph). It was heading west at about 9
mph (14 kph).
	   Hurricanes have minimum sustained wind speeds of 74 mph (119
kph).
	   Forecasters said it Estelle would probably grow to hurricane
force by Friday, but early predictions of the track indicated it
was unlikely to hit land.
	   In Miami, forecasters at the National Hurricane Center said
Friday that tropical storm Alex is weakening, and its winds may
slow enough for it to be downgraded to a tropical depression,
	   ``The good news is that the storm is falling apart,'' center
director Jerry Jarrell said.
	   But there is some bad news.
	   ``There is a very impressive looking wave behind Alex that may
become something,'' Jarrell said. ``That will be at least next week
before we get a look at it.''
	   Alex is centered farther south than previously thought, so it
could move closer to Puerto Rico and other Caribbean islands. But
forecasters say the threat is minimal.
	   At 2100 GMT Friday, Alex was located near 15.8 north latitude,
51.1 west longitude, or about 600 miles (965 kilometers) east of
the Leeward Islands in the eastern Caribbean.
	   The storm's wind speed decreased to near 40 mph (65 kph). It is
moving west at about 12 mph (19 kph). Forecasters say that although
they said Thursday that they expected Alex to reach hurricane
status within two days, strong southerly upper-level winds hit the
storm, weakening it.
	   Forecasters said Alex could be downgraded to a tropical
depression Friday night or Saturday.

NEWS STORY 
 2000-08-14 01:48 
 Alberto weakening; new weather system forms in Gulf  


	   MIAMI (AP) - Hurricane Alberto, once a strong Category 3 storm,
has gradually lost strength as it moves over cooler waters in the
north Atlantic.


   Meanwhile, a tropical depression in the western Gulf of Mexico
could become a tropical storm as early as Monday, forecasters said.


   At 11 p.m. Sunday EDT, Alberto's maximum sustained winds were 80
mph, down from 115 mph the day before. Additional weakening was
forecast over the next three days.


   Alberto was located about 810 miles west of the Azores Islands,
west of Portugal. Alberto was moving at about 16 mph Sunday and
forecasters predicted the storm would gradually continue on this
course for the next 24 hours.


   ''We expect Alberto to continue moving east-northeast and then
it's expected to slow down,'' said James Franklin, a hurricane
specialist at the National Hurricane Center in Miami.


   The tropical depression in the Gulf was stationary at 11 p.m.
EDT. The storm's poorly-defined center was located about 340 miles
southeast of Brownsville, Texas.


   With winds near 35 mph, the depression was expected to begin
moving northwest toward land, forecasters said.


   ''It could be a tropical storm by during the day on Monday,''
said hurricane forecaster Stacy Stewart. ''The center's broad and
disorganized, it will have to pull together a little bit before the
system can get going.''


   Tropical depressions become tropical storms once they reach 40
mph. Tropical storms become hurricanes once their top sustained
winds reach 74 mph.


   Stewart said the depression could reach hurricane intensity as
early as Tuesday.


   ''Residents along the lower Texas coast and in northeastern
Mexico should monitor the progress of this depression,'' Stewart
said.


   ''From Corpus Christi to Tampico, they need to stay aware of
this system,'' Stewart said. ''They need to keep advised on this
system and if they don't have their hurricane-ready emergency kits
together, they need to start doing that now. Don't wait until
watches and warnings are put up on Monday.''


   On the Net: http://www.nhc.noaa.gov

1999-04-30 
 Macao to Be Affected by Tropical Storm Leo 


MACAO, April 30 (Xinhua) -- To be Affected by tropical storm
Leo in the South China Sea, Macao residents will have
deteriorating weathers in the coming days, according to sources
from the local meteorological station.


The Macao Geophysical and Meteorological Station put up a first-
level storm warning sign at 10:30 a.m. on Thursday, when the storm
was centered at about 600 km to the south of Macao. At 10:00 p.m.,
the storm was less than 500 km from Macao.


The sources said higher levels of sign may be hung up on Friday
or later days if the storm moves closer to Macao.


As a result of the tropical storm, Macao had 28.8 mm of
precipitation on Thursday.


It was the first time since 1978 that a first-level storm
warning sign was hung up in April in Macao. Heavy storms normally
occur between May and August.

NEWS STORY 
 2000-09-03 18:44 
 Ernesto Weakens Below Tropical Storm  


   MIAMI (AP) -- Tropical Storm Ernesto, the fifth named storm of
the 2000 hurricane season, deteriorated Sunday, and was not
expected to regenerate, forecasters said.


   The winds accompanying Ernesto dropped to 35 mph Sunday, below
the tropical storm threshold of 39 mph. Strong vertical winds high
in the atmosphere weakened the storm, said Miles Lawrence,
hurricane specialist with the National Hurricane Center in Miami.


   The center of the storm, which formed early Saturday, was about
1,200 miles east-southeast of the Florida coast.

1999-06-16 18:30:19 
 usa 
 Tropical Storm Warning in Bermuda 


	HAMILTON, Bermuda (AP) -- Cruise ships fled Bermuda on Wednesday  
in fear of Tropical Storm Arlene, despite predictions the storm 
would probably miss the islands on its crawl through the Atlantic 
Ocean. 


	By late Wednesday, forecasters said Arlene was barely of  
tropical storm strength, with top sustained winds of 40 mph, down 
from 45 mph earlier Wednesday. Tropical storms have sustained winds 
of at least 39 mph. 


	Forecasters predicted the storm would weaken and turn north  
Thursday, missing the British territory. But residents could expect 
wind and rain, they warned. 


	The Bermuda Weather Service predicted the storm would be at its  
closest point to the islands -- 92 miles away -- at 1 a.m. EDT. 


	Arlene is the first storm of the Atlantic hurricane season.  


	At 8 p.m. EDT, it was centered about 130 miles east-southeast of  
Bermuda and was moving to the north-northwest at 5 mph. 


	Playing it safe, Celebrity cruise line's Zenith Horizon sailed  
to Miami, and the Norwegian Crown and Norwegian Majesty were headed 
for home ports in New York and Boston to avoid the storm. The 
Nordic Empress, which was expected in Bermuda on Wednesday, sailed 
to the Bahamas instead. 


	Arlene's storm-force winds extended 105 miles from its center,  
down from 145 miles. 


	The National Hurricane Center in Miami said the strongest winds  
would probably stay east of Bermuda. 


	Hardware stores were doing a brisk business in batteries and  
portable lights after the storm warning was issued Wednesday, as 
Bermudians prepared for possible power failures.

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-09-16 14:50 
 Gordon expected to become hurricane, strike Florida's Gulf Coast  
By PAT LEISNER


   TAMPA, Fla. (AP) - As Tropical Storm Gordon threatened to become
a hurricane and strike Florida's Gulf Coast, Gov. Jeb Bush on
Saturday activated emergency response teams.


   State officials said they expect Gordon to be a Category 1
hurricane with winds of between 74 and 95 mph when it strikes land
anywhere between Fort Myers and the Panhandle sometime late Sunday.


   Rains of five inches or more are expected and coastal areas
should anticipate a storm surge, said Joe Myers, the state
emergency management director.


   The National Hurricane Center issued a tropical storm warning
Saturday that covered a 210-mile stretch from Bonita Beach just
south of Fort Myers to the Suwanee River, about 100 miles north of
Tampa.


   Forecasters also issued a hurricane watch for a 400-mile stretch
from Bonita Beach to the Panhandle town of Apalachicola. They said
Gordon could reach hurricane strength by late Saturday.


   A tropical storm warning means a storm with winds of between 39
and 73 mph is expected to hit an area within the next 24 hours. A
hurricane watch means a storm with winds of 74 mph or greater could
hit within the next 36 hours.


   At 2 p.m. EDT, Gordon was located near latitude 24.1 north and
longitude 86.1 west - about 345 miles southwest of Tampa. Its winds
have increased from 65 to 70 mph, 4 mph below hurricane strength.


   Two to five inches of rain are expected across portions of South
Florida and the Keys on Saturday, forecasters said.


   Saturday afternoon, counties along central Florida's Gulf Coast
began recommending voluntary evacuation for residents in barrier
islands and coastal or low lying areas.


   Disaster officials in Hernando, Manatee and Pinellas counties
told residents they should start packing, and that shelters would
be opened Saturday evening. Other counties were awaiting later
forecasts before deciding whether of advise their residents to
evacuate.


   The storm is even causing some concern on Florida's Atlantic
coast - at Cape Canaveral, NASA considered Saturday moving space
shuttle Discovery off its seaside launch pad and into it's hangar.
Discovery is scheduled to blast off on a space-station construction
mission on Oct. 5.


   Gordon's affect is already being felt in Cuba and Mexico.


   Heavy rains of seven to 10 inches affected parts of western Cuba
early Saturday, and heavy rains were reported Friday on Mexico's
Yucatan Peninsula. That caused street flooding in the resort city
of Cancun.


   Meanwhile, tropical storm force winds struck Bermuda on Saturday
as Hurricane Florence passed to the island nation's north, but the
storm is not expected to score a direct hit.


   Winds of 60 mph hit Bermuda early Saturday, but no damage was
reported, the National Hurricane Center said.


   At 10 a.m. EDT, Florence was 180 miles north of Bermuda and was
moving to the northeast at 25 mph. Near its center, it still packed
hurricane force winds of 75 mph, but those missed the island,
forecasters said.


   ''There was no structural damage. There was no flooding,'' said
James Buxton, meteorologist with the Bermuda Weather Service. ''For
a few hours, winds reached tropical storm force.''


   Rip currents associated with Florence were blamed for at least
three surf deaths Tuesday in North Carolina.


   Meanwhile, a tropical depression that was sighted in the tropics
early Saturday has been downgraded to a tropical wave because
hurricane hunters could find no clear center of circulation.


   However, the wave is still carrying 35 mph winds and gusts to
tropical storm force in squalls are likely over parts of the
Leewards later Saturday.


   At 1 p.m. EDT, the wave was located about 230 miles east of
Guadeloupe in the Leeward Islands and was moving west near 17 mph.


   A tropical storm watch has been discontinued for the Leeward
Islands.


   On the Net:


   National Hurricane Center: http://www.nhc.noaa.gov


 AP-ES-09-16-00 1450

it could go closer to the islands than previously anticipated, he

the short term as it advances with 50 mph (80 kph) winds toward the

	   ``(It's not) particularly bad news for Puerto Rico and the
(Virgin) Islands,'' Jarrell said. ``It looks like it wouldn't be
much of a storm, even if it gets there,'' in two or three days.

late Friday to be recategorized as a tropical depression. It is
expected to continue moving near 12 mph (19 kph) to the west
northwest, he said.

NEWS STORY 
 2000-08-20 23:49 
 Tropical Storm Debby Forms  
By ADRIAN SAINZ


   MIAMI (AP) -- Tropical Storm Debby formed Sunday in the western
Atlantic, gathering strength gradually as it moved toward the U.S.
Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico.


   The storm could become a hurricane by Tuesday afternoon, said
Krissy Williams, a meteorologist at the National Hurricane Center
in Miami.


   ''It's not intensifying as rapidly as expected,'' Williams said.
''But once it starts getting into warmer waters, it should start to
intensify more.''


   A hurricane watch was issued Sunday for St. Maarten, Saba and
St. Eustatius and the U.S. Virgin Islands. A tropical storm watch
was issued for Antigua, Barbuda and Anguilla and could be upgraded
to a hurricane watch by Monday morning, forecasters said.


   Debby likely will move over Antigua, Guadeloupe and the rest of
the Leeward Islands early Tuesday and the British Virgin Islands
later Tuesday, if the storm remains on its current west-northwest
track, Williams said.


   At 11 p.m. EDT, Debby's top sustained winds were near 50 mph --
the threshold for tropical storms is 39 mph. It was located about
550 miles east of the Leeward Islands and was moving west northwest
at 18 mph.


   Its track had it heading toward Puerto Rico and the northern
U.S. Virgin Islands after it passes the Leeward Islands.


   ''If they haven't already, people in the lesser Antilles and
Puerto Rico need to go out now and get all the essentials they
need,'' said Stacy Stewart, a hurricane specialist. ''This system
needs to be taken seriously.''


   In Antigua, authorities urged farmers to reap any crops they
could before Debby arrived in the area. The British territory of
Anguilla, where Hurricanes Jose and Lenny caused widespread
flooding last year, activated its disaster preparedness agency and
warned small boats to stay in port.


   Elsewhere, long-lived Hurricane Alberto was still spiraling in
the open Atlantic and former Tropical Storm Chris had all but
fizzled.


   Alberto, the longest-lived August tropical storm on record, kept
going strong Sunday with top sustained wind of about 100 mph. It
was located 1,070 miles west of the Azores and was moving north at
about 6 mph.


   Alberto formed Aug. 4 and hasn't threatened land.


   The remnants of Chris had deteriorated into a weak tropical wave
several hundred miles east of the Bahamas with no immediate
strengthening expected.


   ------


   On the Net:


   National Hurricane Center: http://www.nhc.noaa.gov

1999-06-14 20:20:15 
 usa 
 Bermuda Issues Tropical Storm Watch 


	MIAMI (AP) -- The first storm of the Atlantic hurricane season  
headed northwest Monday across the north Atlantic, prompting a 
tropical storm watch for Bermuda. 


	Tropical Storm Arlene had winds of 45 mph, down from 50 mph  
earlier in the day and 60 mph Sunday night. 


	The storm is expected to miss the United States by curving away  
into the open ocean before reaching the coast. 


	``I don't think the East Coast is in the future of this storm,''  
hurricane specialist Miles Lawrence said. 


	He said the storm was on track toward Bermuda, which could feel  
high winds by Tuesday night if the storm does not change course. 


	At 11 p.m. EDT, Arlene's center was about 255 miles southeast of  
Bermuda. It was moving northwest and was expected to continue in 
that direction at 5 mph. 


	Storms in this part of the Atlantic often turn toward the  
northeast and die at sea as they enter cooler waters, which 
discourage development.

results.content:
&HT;   



   ATLANTA -- So what's with a hurricane named Georges?


   If we're up to the G's, why not plain old George or Gus or Gary?


   According to the National Weather Service, the name of the
latest tropical menace is George, only it's the French spelling and
pronunciation.


   After all, hurricanes aren't just for Americans.


   Flashes of international culture are reflected in the 1998 list
of tropical storms and hurricane names.


   Because hurricanes affect countries worldwide, weather watchers
can say adios to standard American names like Bob and Betsy, both
of which have been retired.


   National Weather Service spokesman Curtis Carey said forecasters
have been frustrated by the mispronunciation of the latest tropical
storm, the French-inspired Georges, which was christened Wednesday.


   ``Using the European pronunciation is the way most people at the
weather service do it,'' said Carey, who works at the regional
weather service office in Fort Worth, Texas.


   The Dutch name Hermine is next in line for the weather
disturbance currently brewing in the Gulf of Mexico. Coming later
in 1998 _ if the storms develop _ will be Ivan, Otto, Danielle and
Nicole in the Atlantic.


   Eastern and Central Pacific storms will have names like Blas,
Isis, Orlene, Xavier and Zeke.


   A storm is given a name only when it reaches a wind speed of
about 40 mph and evolves from a tropical depression into a tropical
storm.


   Hurricane names are selected by members of the World
Meteorological Organization, Carey said.


   They are revised about every six years. If a storm was
especially destructive, its name is retired.


   In his Web site, Arizona meteorologist Ed Phillips says before
hurricanes were named, weather forecasters labeled storms with
numbers and letters.


   This eventually led to naming hurricanes after weather service
employees, and that evolved into the current alphabetical list .


   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers


   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service

NEWS STORY 
 2000-09-22 01:45 
 Tropical Storm Heads to Gulf Coast  
By BILL KACZOR


   PENSACOLA, Fla. (AP) -- Storm warnings were posted along the Gulf
Coast on Thursday after Tropical Storm Helene formed and quickly
gained strength in the Gulf of Mexico.


   The center of the storm was expected to make landfall sometime
Friday near Fort Walton Beach, east of Pensacola. A hurricane watch
was posted for much of the western Florida coast and at least 5 to
8 inches of rain were expected in many areas.


   ''At this moment, we do not feel it's going to actually reach
hurricane strength,'' said Robert Molleda, a forecaster with the
National Hurricane Center in Miami. ''It'll mostly be a rain
event.''


   At 11 p.m., the storm was centered 95 miles south of Pensacola
with sustained winds of near 65 mph. It was moving at 15 mph.


   ''It's not that strong,'' said Bob McCabe at his home at Navarre
Beach, 20 miles east of Pensacola. ''I'm hoping it hits east of
here. ... I'd rather see it fizzle.''


   Evacuations normally are not required with a storm of Helene's
predicted intensity, but authorities along the Gulf Coast prepared
disaster plans anyway.


   Shelters were opened, military planes were evacuated from bases
in the Florida Panhandle and schools districts in Okaloosa, Walton
and Santa Rosa counties canceled Friday classes. Government offices
also were closed in Okaloosa County.


   Helene was expected to cause storm-surge flooding of up to 5
feet above normal tide levels in some places, said Jack Beven, a
specialist with the hurricane center.


   Tropical storm warnings stretched from Pascagoula, Miss. to
Florida's Aucilla River, southeast of Tallahassee. Flood warnings
were posted for parts of the Florida coast, still soggy from the
weekend passage of Tropical Storm Gordon, and a flood watch was
posted in northern Georgia.


   Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Isaac, which strengthened from a
depression late Thursday, posed no threat to land. The storm is in
the far eastern Atlantic, south of the Cape Verde Islands off
northwestern Africa.


   ------


   On the Net:


   National Hurricane Center: http://www.nhc.noaa.gov

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-05-10 15:55 
 Stronger Hurricanes Forecast in 2000  
By RANDOLPH E. SCHMID, Associated Press Writer


   WASHINGTON (AP) -- Hurricane season is fast approaching and the
outlook isn't pretty.


   Federal storm specialists predicted an above-average storm
season Wednesday, calling for stronger, longer-lasting storms this
year, and more of them.


   Hurricane season officially begins June 1, and the outlook is
for 11 tropical storms, seven of which will be hurricanes, three of
them major.


   ''This puts coastal areas and the Caribbean islands at a much
higher risk of experiencing a tropical storm or hurricane,'' said
D. James Baker, head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric
Administration.


   The forecast is similar to last year's, which was followed by a
series of serious storms, including Hurricane Floyd, that caused
massive evacuations along the Southeastern coast and then inundated
North Carolina.


   The La Nina cooling of water in the Pacific Ocean, the same
condition that influenced the 1999 season, remains in place, Baker
said.


   ''For this reason we expect we'll have another major economic
impact on the United States,'' he said.


   ''It's not just about the number'' of storms, added Max
Mayfield, director of the National Hurricane Center in Miami.
''What really counts is where they make landfall and how strong
they are. Just one hurricane over your community makes it a very
bad year.''


   James Lee Witt, director of the Federal Emergency Management
Agency, stressed the importance of having a plan and being prepared
for the storms. He cited community efforts, including Project
Impact, which helps people strengthen their homes against storms of
all types.


   Baker and Witt signed a memorandum pledging to work closely
together to warn people of impending storms and help them prepare.


   ''It doesn't matter how good the forecast is if people don't
plan in advance,'' said Jack Kelly, director of the National
Weather Service.


   Last year's evacuations left thousands of people trapped on
jammed highways for hours and the forecasters said that is a
problem they hope to avoid in the future. Coastal areas subject to
flooding need to be evacuated in storms, but not every place that
merely expects wind damage, they said.


   ''You flee from storm surge, you hide from wind,'' said
Mayfield, calling on people to get storm shutters, build safe rooms
and take other steps to prepare their homes.


   The new outlook from the government forecasters echoes that of
Bill Gray of Colorado State University, one of the few willing to
make long-range storm predictions. For this season he also
predicted 11 named storms.


   Mayfield was picked last week to replace the retired Jerry
Jarrell as director of the hurricane center.


   Also last week a new weather satellite was launched that can be
pressed into service this summer if needed. The $220 million GOES-L
satellite had been delayed a year.


   The forecasters rely on two Geostationary Operational
Environmental Satellites to monitor tropical storms and other
severe weather. The East Coast's GOES-8, however, is a year beyond
its design lifetime. Although still working, it could break down at
any moment. GOES-L is a crucial backup.


   While some climate experts have been blaming the increase in
tropical storms in recent years on global warming, Gray says the
trend is cyclical and not related to warming.


   Asked about this Wednesday, Baker agreed. ''We don't see, at
this point, a link between global warming and tropical cyclone
activity,'' he said.


   Tropical cyclones is another name for hurricanes, which are also
called typhoons in some parts of the world.


   Over the last three decades forecasters have gotten better at
predicting where the storms will go, researchers Colin McAdie and
Miles Lawrence report in the May issue of the Bulletin of the
American Meteorological Society.


   They found that from 1970 to 1998 track forecast errors
decreased by about 1 percent per year for the 24-hour forecast.

Hurricane Isaac's Winds Lessen  


   MIAMI (AP) -- Hurricane Isaac remained deep in the Atlantic and
posed no immediate threat to land as its winds decreased to 105 mph
Monday. Farther away, Tropical Storm Joyce formed off West Africa.


   Monday night, Isaac was about 1,280 miles east of the northern
Leeward Islands, at the eastern edge of the Caribbean, and moving
to the west-northwest at near 9 mph, according to the National
Hurricane Center in Miami.


   ''It's very far from land and in three days it's still going to
be very far away from the islands,'' said hurricane specialist
James Franklin. ''If it continues on its present track, it would
pass well north of the islands.''


   Forecasters also were tracking a tropical depression about 570
miles west-southwest of the Cape Verde Islands that became Tropical
Storm Joyce late Monday.


   Its top sustained winds were 40 mph, 1 mph over the threshold at
which a tropical depression becomes a named tropical storm.
Tropical storms become hurricanes when their top winds reach 74
mph.


   Hurricane specialist Jack Beven said the Joyce posed no
immediate threat to land.

results.content:
Depression in Caribbean Sea could become tropical storm


	   MIAMI (AP) _ A tropical depression over the Caribbean Sea was
expected to strengthen into a tropical storm Thursday.
	   An advisory was in effect for the North Atlantic, Caribbean Sea
and the Gulf of Mexico, forecasters at the National Hurricane
Center said.
	   A large area of disturbed weather changed little in organization
overnight but was beginning to interact with a frontal system,
increasing the system's potential to become a tropical storm.
	   Sustained wind near the center was blowing at about 35 mph and
was likely to reach tropical storm strength of at least 39 mph
Thursday afternoon, forecaster Ed Rappaport said.
	   At 11 a.m. EDT, the center of the poorly organized depression
was located near 12.0 north latitude and 78.0 west longitude, or
about 420 miles south-southwest of Kingston, Jamaica.
	   A reconnaissance plane was scheduled to fly into the area
Thursday if necessary, Rappaport said.
	   The combination of the depression and a cold front was forecast
to continue producing rain and gusty winds over northeastern Mexico
and portions of the southern Texas coast.

results.content:
1999-08-25 19:00:19 
 usa 
 Tropical Storm Heads Toward U.S. 


	NASSAU, Bahamas (AP) -- Tropical Storm Dennis gathered strength  
as it stalled off the southern Bahamas Wednesday, with forecasters 
warning it could become a hurricane overnight and threaten the 
islands. 


	The U.S. National Hurricane Center in Miami urged people on the  
southeast coast of the United States, primarily North and South 
Carolina, to closely monitor Dennis. 


	Anticipating possible heavy rains, the South Florida Water  
Management District on Wednesday started to drain canals to stave 
off flooding. 


	``The uncertainty is killing us,'' said district spokeswoman Ann  
Overton. 


	Bahamians took a nonchalant attitude, though a hurricane watch  
and tropical storm warnings were posted Wednesday. 


	``I think some degree of complacency has developed in the  
Bahamas because we have had the good fortune of escaping a direct 
hit of a hurricane for a number of years,'' said Godwin Blyden of 
the Bahamas National Disaster Organization. 


	At 5 p.m. EDT, Dennis was centered near 23.1 north latitude,  
72.1 west longitude, 60 miles east-northeast of the island of 
Mayaguana and about 365 miles east-southeast of Nassau, the 
Bahamian capital. 


	The storm slowed to a crawl and gained strength, with top  
sustained winds at 65 mph, just shy of hurricane strength, but 
concentrated on its eastern section facing open seas. Tropical 
storm force winds extended up to 70 miles from its center. Dennis 
was expected to resume a slow west-northwest track later Wednesday. 


	Forecasts had the storm reaching hurricane strength Wednesday  
night or Thursday. 


	``It's looking like it's going to be in the central Bahamas by  
Thursday,'' said meteorologist Trisha Wallace at the National 
Hurricane Center in Miami. 


	Dennis was one of three tropical storms in the area. Emily  
sprang up Tuesday at near hurricane strength, surprising 
forecasters who hadn't even thought it was a depression. Wednesday 
morning, they warned people in the Lesser Antilles islands in the 
southeastern Caribbean to monitor the storm. 


	But Emily weakened quickly and at 5 p.m. EDT had top winds of 45  
mph and was centered near 13.4 north latitude, 55.7 west longitude, 
about 255 miles east of Barbados. It was moving toward the 
northwest near 7 mph with little change expected. 


	Emily may tangle with Tropical Storm Cindy, which was near  
hurricane strength with winds of 70 mph, but far out in the 
Atlantic with no threat to land. Meteorologists explained that if 
the storms do combine, the resulting system would not suddenly 
become twice as strong.

results.content:
1998-10-30 
 "Mitch" Becomes Tropical Storm, Disaster Continues 


TEGUCIGALPA, Oct 29 (Xinhua) -- Hurricane "Mitch," which has
been slashing at Honduras for the fourth consecutive day, became a
tropical storm Thursday, a Contingencies Permanent Commission
(COPECO) source said.


Col. Anahel Perez told the press that hurricane "Mitch," which
remained off the Honduran coast at mid-day of Thursday, "has
ceased to be a hurricane and now is a tropical storm," with the
same force it had when it began across the Colombian coast last
week.


However, rain continues in the north and Caribbean regions of
Honduras, so its influence will continue.


The storm could recover its strength and continue in the next
hours toward the west, so its presence is still a threat for
Central America, said a source of the National Hurricane Center in
Miami.


Meanwhile, a yacht with 31 people aboard was missing Thursday
in the storm-roiled Caribbean, where Hurricane Mitch killed 32
people before being downgraded to a tropical storm.


A U.S. Coast Guard airplane was searching for the boat, while
storm-driven floodwaters continued to rise on shore, cutting some
Central American communities off from food, water and medicine.


Incessant rain along the coast has flooded at least 50 rivers
in Honduras, knocking out bridges and highways and putting many
towns under water. More than 150,000 people were forced to seek
higher ground in the region, including Honduras, Nicaragua, Belize
and Mexico.

1999-05-22 10:11:55 
 usa 
 1998 Hurricane Season One of Worst 


	The 1998 Atlantic hurricane season started slow, but became one  
of the deadliest on record. Of 14 named storms, nine became 
hurricanes. 


	-- Tropical Storm Alex (July 27-Aug. 2): Never threatened land.  


	-- Hurricane Bonnie (Aug. 19-30): Danced around the U.S.  
coastline before hitting North Carolina with wind gusts up to 100 
mph, caused $1 billion damage. 


	-- Tropical Storm Charley (Aug. 21-Aug. 22): Made landfall in  
Texas, causing flooding inland and killing at least 19 people. 
Eighteen inches of rain fell in some areas. 


	-- Hurricane Daniel (Aug. 24-Sept. 3.): With 100 mph winds, it  
came within 455 miles west of Bermuda. 


	-- Hurricane Earl (Aug. 31-Sept. 3): Dumped nearly 2 feet of rain  
on the Florida Panhandle with 80 mph winds. About $25 million in 
insured losses and three reported deaths. 


	-- Tropical Storm Frances (Sept. 8-11): Flooded more than 300  
miles of Gulf Coast from Texas to Louisiana. 


	-- Hurricane Georges (Sept. 15-29): A Category 4 storm with  
maximum sustained winds near 150 mph. Killed more than 500 people 
in Haiti and the Dominican Republic and destroyed $2 billion in 
insured property in four Gulf Coast states and the Caribbean. There 
was $250 million in damage to the Florida Keys. 


	-- Tropical Storm Hermine (Sept. 17-20): Never threatened land.  


	-- Hurricane Ivan (Sept. 20-26): Posed threat to the Azores.  


	-- Hurricane Jeanne (Sept. 21-30): Never moved out of the eastern  
Atlantic Ocean. 


	-- Hurricane Karl (Sept. 25-27): Never threatened land but was  
historic because it marked the first time since 1893 that the 
Atlantic-Gulf regions played host to four hurricanes at once. 
Georges, Ivan and Jeanne were the other three. 


	-- Hurricane Lisa (Oct. 5-9): Never threatened land.  


	-- Hurricane Mitch (Oct. 22-Nov. 6): The third deadliest  
hurricane on record. A Category 5 storm with sustained winds over 
155 mph. It stalled over Honduras, causing at least 10,000 deaths 
in Central America. It reformed in the Gulf as a tropical storm and 
tracked a path through the Florida Keys. 


	-- Tropical Storm Nicole (Nov. 24): Never threatened land.

 usa 
 Hurricane Watch Posted in Bahamas 


	MIAMI (AP) -- A hurricane watch was posted today for the Bahamas  
as forecasters warned that Tropical Storm Dennis could affect the 
southeastern United States by this weekend. 


	Dennis was 320 miles east-southeast of Nassau at 5 a.m. EDT and  
moving toward the islands at about 8 mph. Its top winds were nearly 
45 mph. 


	The central Bahamas were under a tropical storm warning. The  
hurricane watch covered the Turks, Caicos and other Bahama islands 
-- including Bimini, just 55 miles from Florida. 


	``It's looking like it's going to be in the central Bahamas by  
Thursday,'' said Trisha Wallace, a meteorologist at the National 
Hurricane Center in Miami. 


	Strong winds from Dennis extended up to 70 miles from its center  
today. 


	``Residents along the entire southeastern United States coast  
should closely monitor the progress of this system,'' said 
hurricane specialist Jack Beven of the hurricane center. 


	Dennis is one of three tropical storms the meteorologists were  
watching. 


	Emily sprang up in the Caribbean on Tuesday, surprising  
forecasters who hadn't thought it was even a tropical depression. 
Early today, the storm was 455 miles east of the Windward Islands, 
the southern Lesser Antilles. Its top winds also were 45 mph, with 
little change expected before Thursday. 


	The storm was moving to the northwest at 6 mph.  


	Emily may tangle with Tropical Storm Cindy, which was far out in  
the Atlantic. 


	``Emily could dissipate and essentially be sucked up into  
Cindy,'' Wallace said. ``It could also be the other way around.'' 


	She said a combined storm would not necessarily be twice as  
powerful. Beven said Emily could reach hurricane strength by 
Friday, if it stays far enough away from Cindy. 


	At 5 a.m. EDT, Cindy was about 1,100 miles east of the Leeward  
Islands. The storm was traveling west-northwest at 14 mph with top 
winds of 65 mph. 


	Cindy was forecast to swing gradually north and stay over the  
open ocean.

1996-09-26 
 Tropical Storms Kill 456 in Vietnam 


HANOI, September 26 (Xinhua) -- At least 456 people were killed
and 668 injured during the tropical storms hitting vietnam's
northern and central coastal regions in the past two months, the
local press reported today.


The hardest hit areas were those coastal provinces in the Red
River delta and those on the northern part of the central coast.


The narrow strip along the central coast, hemmed in between the
Truong Son mountain range and the sea, is prone to almost all
storms and tropical low atmospheric depressions formed in the
South China Sea.


Vietnam's Central Committee for Floods and Storms Control
warned that the storm season will last at least another two
months.
