results.content:
TROPICAL STORM HARVEY DOES NOT PACK MUCH OF A PUNCH 



   MIAMI _ As Floridians asked themselves how anyone could be all
that afraid of a tropical storm named Harvey, people in the
southern tip of the state wearily endured this latest bout with bad
weather with more impatience than trepidation.


   An unexpected change in direction shifted the ragged tropical
storm away from the densely populated Tampa Bay area and into
Florida's southwestern Gulf Coast. Although the storm forced the
closing of schools and triggered an emergency declaration from Gov.
Jeb Bush, in the end heavy rains and some flooding were the worst
the storm could do.


   In fact, said environmentalists, the state needed the heavy
rains in its South Florida wetlands to help replenish the aquifer
and swamps so that fish, wading birds and other wildlife will have
enough water to make it through the dry season this winter.


   The tropical storm came ashore less than a week after Hurricane
Floyd, a massive storm four times the size of the destructive
Hurricane Andrew in 1992, pounded the Bahamas and skirted the
Florida coastline before blowing along the Eastern Seaboard,
killing more than 60 people.


   The center of Harvey, with winds around 50 mph, came ashore
Tuesday morning in Collier County on the Gulf Coast. Then, with
winds weakening to below 40 mph, the tropical strom washed across
the Everglades before bringing rain into Miami and the rest of
South Florida.


   Forecasters had feared that the storm would enter the state at
Tampa Bay and head northeast, perhaps bringing more hard rain and
misery to the Carolinas, which were ravaged by floods from
Hurricane Floyd. But instead, the storm weakened Tuesday and a cold
front turned the storm to the southeast, across the state's
southern peninsula and into the Atlantic.


   With the Tampa area spared the brunt of the storm Tuesday, a
cruise ship was able to limp back to port under the power of one
engine. On Sunday, an engine room fire had knocked out both
engines, stranding the ship and the 1,700 people aboard in the Gulf
of Mexico.


   With the storm's new course, its impact on the Carolinas, if
any, would be slight, said weather experts at the National
Hurricane Center in Miami.


   ``This isn't anything to worry about by any means,'' said Lixion
Avila, a hurricane specialist with the National Hurricane Center,
as the storm staggered across the southern tip of the state and
took aim at the open Atlantic. ``This is a poorly defined tropical
storm. It will dump some rain. It will only move around a couple of
tree branches and lightweight street debris. That's all.''


   (STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)


   The storm deluged Collier County with some 10 inches of rain,
flooding streets and sending water into 35 homes and about the same
number of businesses, said Ken Pineau, the emergency management
director for Collier County.


   In Everglades City, a town of about 600 people some 40 miles
east of Naples, Martha Daniels, the city clerk, sat in her office
and watched the streets flood all around City Hall.


   ``City Hall is an island,'' she said. ``We're watching the tide
go by. We see these little reddish-brown piles floating by _
millions of ants on top of each other. We saw a telephone pole go
by a while ago. Now we're seeing somebody go by in a canoe. You
can't tell what's road, what's lawn. It all looks the same under
water.''


   But no one seemed to be panicking. In the nearby small town of
Ochopee, Vince Doerr, a retired firefighter, watched the heavy
rains more with interest than fear.


   ``We can take it better than they can in Miami, I guess on
account of all those roads and shopping centers,'' Doerr said. ``It
slows the water down. Here it flows real natural.''


   The storm was expected to bring rains of from 2 to 5 inches to
the Miami area.


   Meanwhile, environmentalists were grateful for the rain.


   ``These rains are crucial,'' said Ed Carlson, manager of the
Corkscrew Swamp Sanctuary, about 30 miles north of Naples. ``This
is the kind of rain that co

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-09-22 16:04 
 Tropical Storm Helene hits Florida Panhandle with heavy rains  
By DARA KAM


   TALLAHASSEE, Fla. (AP) - A rapidly weakening Tropical Storm
Helene sloshed ashore Friday in the Florida Panhandle, bringing
bands of heavy rain but only minor damage.


   Helene had dumped 7.75 inches of rain on Tallahassee by 2 p.m.,
flooding roads, ditches and a couple of apartment buildings, said
Ann Rowe, a spokeswoman for the Florida Division of Emergency
Management.


   The storm spun off at least six tornados south of Tallahassee,
but no significant damage was reported in the lightly populated
area, officials said.


   ''What storm?'' asked Charles Ingram, 62, a retired paper mill
worker, at breakfast at Linda's Restaurant in Port St. Joe, which
got some of the heaviest rain.


   ''There's an awful lot of water standing around, which we
need,'' Ingram said. ''We had a lot of lightning, a lot of rain,
but not much damage. It's just business as usual. We planned for
it, sandbagged and everything, but it didn't come.''


   Schools throughout the Panhandle and state offices in
Tallahassee had closed in anticipation of the storm. Power outages
left 5,000 people in the dark and Tallahassee buses stopped running
during the storm, officials said.


   Helene's center made landfall with top winds near 45 mph - down
from 65 mph - at about 8 a.m. near Fort Walton Beach, but the
heaviest rain of up to 8 inches was 100 to 150 miles east of the
center, including Tallahassee.


   ''We get geared up and don't get hit; who's complaining?'' said
Craig Fugate, leader of the state's emergency response team in
Tallahassee.


   By 2 p.m. the center of Helene, downgraded to a tropical
depression with maximum sustained winds of 35 mph, was 20 miles
north of Dothan, Ala. It was moving northeast at 16 mph.


   Marshall Nelson, Gulf County emergency management coordinator,
estimated between $100,000 to $300,000 in road and beach erosion
damage at Cape San Blas.


   About 130 people stayed in shelters overnight, mostly in
Escambia and Santa Rosa counties, in the western end of the
Panhandle.


   Some flood warnings remained in effect for parts of Florida,
including areas still soggy from the weekend passage of Tropical
Storm Gordon. A flood watch was posted in northern Georgia.
Tropical storm warnings, which had stretched from Pascagoula,
Miss., to southeast of Tallahassee, were lifted after the storm
made landfall.


   Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Isaac, which strengthened from a
depression late Thursday, was in the far eastern Atlantic on Friday
and posed no threat to land. The storm, with maximum sustained
winds of nearly 50 mph, moving toward the west-northwest at nearly
18 mph.


   On the Net:


   National Hurricane Center: http://www.nhc.noaa.gov


 AP-ES-09-22-00 1604

1999-09-20 03:30:09 
 usa 
 Hurricane Watch Issued for Bermuda 


	MIAMI (AP) -- Bermuda was under a tropical storm warning early  
today as Hurricane Gert moved closer, while western Florida 
prepared for rain and wind stirred up by Tropical Storm Harvey. 


	At 5 a.m. EDT, Hurricane Gert was 395 miles southeast of Bermuda  
and moving to the northwest at nearly 13 mph. Its top sustained 
winds had slowed slightly to 125 mph, but Bermuda remained under a 
hurricane watch issued by the National Hurricane Center in Miami. 


	The storm was expected to make a gradual turn to the north, but  
Bermuda residents began heading to grocery stores for supplies 
Sunday. 


	``It's a threat to Bermuda ... it's a strong storm,'' said  
public safety minister Paula Cox. 


	The last time Bermuda suffered major damage from a hurricane was  
in 1987, when Hurricane Emily hit the island, moved offshore, then 
struck again. 


	By early today, the tropical depression circulating in the Gulf  
of Mexico had become Tropical Storm Harvey, with top sustained 
winds of nearly 45 mph. 


	A tropical storm watch was issued for much of Florida's western  
coast, from the Suwanee River north of Cedar Key to Bonita Springs 
north of Naples. 


	At 5 a.m. EDT, Harvey was 305 miles southwest of St. Petersburg  
and not moving much. The storm was expected to pick up speed as it 
moves to the northeast and forecasters warned that it could bring 
several inches of rain to central Florida by Tuesday. 


	Harvey could come ashore north of Tampa, cross Florida on  
Tuesday, then shoot into the Atlantic with 60 mph winds, hurricane 
specialist Brian Jarvinen said. 


	In the Pacific, Hurricane Hilary made its debut Sunday off the  
coast of Mexico but was expected to weaken. It was more than 200 
miles southwest of Baja California, traveling to the northwest at 
about 12 mph.

Bonnie becomes hurricane


	   NASSAU, Bahamas (AP) _ Bonnie strengthened into the Atlantic
season's first hurricane Saturday and headed toward sparsely
populated Bahamian islands, on a route that could threaten the
southeastern United States.
	   Another storm was gaining strength in the Pacific Ocean.
	   ``It's definitely going to happen. The southeastern portion (of
the Bahamas) is going to be hit today,'' meteorologist Dave Chorney
said from the U.S. National Hurricane Center in Miami.
	   Bahamian radio warned the islands' fishing fleet and yachters to
make for safe port. The islands' meteorological department said
Bonnie would hit landfall in the southeast later Saturday and pass
by Long Island, Eleuthera and the Abacos over the next 48 to 72
hours.
	   The small islands would have little effect on Hurricane Bonnie,
which is expected to gather strength Saturday.
	   ``Definitely, it's getting stronger,'' said Jerry Jarrell,
director of National Hurricane Center. ``People along the
southeastern U.S. should pay attention to its progress.'' He said
winds could reach 100 mph (160 kph) by Monday though Chorney said
the worst thunderstorms were on the northern side of Bonnie, in the
open Atlantic.
	   Bonnie was about 200 miles (320 kilometers) north of Puerto Rico
early Saturday with top winds near 75 mph (121 kph), just over the
hurricane threshold of 74 mph (120 kph).
	   For Bonnie, the government of the Bahamas issued a tropical
storm warning and a hurricane watch for the southeastern Bahamas
and the Turks and Caicos Islands and a hurricane watch for the
central Bahamas.
	   North Florida is more likely than any other region to be hit if
the storm reaches shore. Still, the storm could veer out to sea and
miss the U.S. coast entirely, Jarrell said.
	   Another weather system, Tropical Storm Charley, threatened parts
of Texas. Tropical storm warnings were posted from Brownsville to
High Island, near Galveston, after a tropical depression formed in
the western Gulf of Mexico.
	   The system generated sustained winds of more than 39 mph (63
kph) by Friday afternoon, enough to make it a tropical storm. Early
Saturday, the storm was center about 50 miles (80 kilometers)
southeast of Port Aransas, Texas.
	   Hundreds of workers were evacuated Friday from offshore oil rigs
as a safety precaution, Coast Guard Petty Officer Rusty Miller
said.
	   Also Friday, a storm in the Pacific Ocean reached hurricane
strength but remained far off the Mexican coast. Hurricane Howard
was 400 miles (645 kilometers) south-southwest of Acapulco late
Friday night and was slowly moving northwest.
	   Howard had sustained winds of 98 mph (158 kph) and gusts up to
121 mph (195 kph). Authorities closed the Acapulco port and warned
ships to be cautious of high waves along the southwestern Mexican
coast.
	   The Atlantic Basin typically has nine tropical storms each year
with six of them becoming hurricanes, two of them intense. In 1997,
there were seven named storms, three hurricanes and one intense
hurricane.

results.content:
1999-09-21 10:09:39 
 usa 
 Tropical Storm Churns Closer to Fla. 


	MIAMI (AP) -- Tropical Storm Harvey changed course and bore down  
on southern Florida today with 50 mph wind and heavy rain, closing 
schools and prompting an emergency declaration from the governor. 


	More than 10 inches of rain had caused some street flooding  
today in parts of Collier County, on the Gulf Coast west of the 
Miami area, the National Weather Service said. 


	The storm's outer bands dropped lesser amounts of rain  
elsewhere, including about an inch in Miami-Dade and Broward 
counties. 


	The heart of the storm was expected to come ashore tonight near  
Naples, in Collier County. 


	The weather service reported two possible tornadoes in western  
Miami-Dade County. 


	Harvey weakened slightly and veered to the southeast early  
today, bringing out tropical storm warnings for southern Florida, 
including the Keys island chain. 


	After crossing Florida, the storm was expected to turn onto a  
more easterly course and head northeast into the Atlantic. A 
tropical storm warning also was posted for the Bahamas. 


	Earlier predictions had the storm making landfall near Tampa, on  
Florida's western coast, then moving along the coast with a threat 
of more heavy rain for flood-stricken North Carolina. 


	Now, said Todd Kimberlain, a meteorologist at the National  
Hurricane Center, ``in the end it may not have much impact at all'' 
on the Carolinas. 


	At 11 a.m., the storm was centered about 30 miles south of  
Naples, and was moving to the east-southeast at 12 mph. Tropical 
storm-force wind of at least 39 mph extended out some 115 miles. 


	``The center is not really well defined. It's just kind of a  
raggedy system,'' said Stephen Baig, oceanographer at the National 
Hurricane Center in Miami. 


	Gov. Jeb Bush on Monday declared a state of emergency for 56 of  
67 counties in anticipation of the storm. Harvey could produce 
storm surge flooding of up to 6 feet above normal in some places. 


	Schools closed for the day in the Florida Keys, in Collier  
County and in the Lee County-Fort Myers area, mostly out of concern 
for street flooding. 


	But most voluntary evacuations called for in the Tampa area --  
advising people living in mobile homes, recreational vehicles, 
coastal and low-lying areas to move -- were lifted today. 


	Out in the Atlantic, a hurricane warning was in effect for  
Bermuda as Gert moved to within 135 miles of the island this 
morning with top wind of 110 mph. It was moving toward the north at 
about 13 mph.

results.content:
WEATHER 



   &QL;


   NATIONAL FORECAST &QL;


   Torrential rains will persist in south-central Texas on Saturday
as the remnants of Tropical Storm Frances meander farther inland.
Serious flooding is possible if the rain bands linger over the hill
country near San Antonio. Another large cluster of gusty
thundershowers will drench Louisiana, western Mississippi and
southern Alabama. The shield of clouds associated with this
tropical system will stretch from the Big Bend of Texas to the
southern Ozarks and eastward to the South Carolina coast.


   Unseasonably warm air will sweep into the Northeast on balmy
breezes from the southwest. Sunshine will be dimmed by intervals of
clouds and it will become more humid. Meanwhile, a weakening cold
front moving east from the Great Lakes will trigger a few
thundershowers in the northern Appalachians. The Northeast Coast
will be bright and very warm.


   A wedge of slightly cooler, but noticeably drier air will occupy
the upper Great Lakes. High pressure will glide east toward
northern New England and this will help push a cold front into
southern New England by Sunday morning.


   Heavy rain will fall in the western Dakotas, eastern Montana and
parts of Wyoming as low pressure forms over the region. A stream of
moisture from the Tropics will produce afternoon thunderstorms in
the central Rockies and northern Arizona. High pressure building
into British Columbia will cause the surface winds to blow offshore
from San Francisco to the Columbia River. As a result, warmer air
will be drawn toward portions of the Pacific Coast under mainly
sunny skies. &QL;


   Focus: Notorious Rainmakers &QL;


   Dying tropical storms are notorious for producing heavy rain
over the hill country of Texas after they make landfall and churn
west. Last month, the remnants of west-bound Tropical Storm Charley
dumped prodigious rains over Del Rio, Texas. Though winds decrease
after landfall, dying tropical systems still retain much of their
original dowries of moisture. As tropical air reaches the hill
country, it ascends the sloping terrain, boosting the lift needed
for intensifying rains. Saturday, the remnants of Tropical Storm
Francis will likely follow the very wet lead of Tropical Storm
Charley.

 Arlene Weakens As It Passes Bermuda 


	MIAMI (AP) -- Arlene, the first storm of the Atlantic hurricane  
season, weakened into a tropical depression Thursday after sweeping 
past Bermuda. 


	What had been tropical storm Arlene was heading north, posing no  
threat to land, with sustained winds near 35 mph, the National 
Hurricane Center in Miami reported. Tropical storms have sustained 
winds of at least 39 mph. 


	Playing it safe Wednesday, cruise ships left early or steered  
clear of Bermuda, but the island was unscathed. 


	The tropical depression is expected to break up by the end of  
the week.

results.content:
1998-08-05 
 Tropical Storm Otto Hits Fujian 


FUZHOU, August 5 (Xinhua) -- Tropical storm Otto reached
Gaoshan Town of Fuqing City in east China's Fujian Province at 2
a.m. today.


The most serious damage is in an area 25.5 degrees north
latitude and 119.5 degrees east longitude, which was struck by
gale-force winds. When Otto arrived, it dumped moderate rainfall
in the central and southern parts of Fujian, according to local
sources.


The tropical storm was formed in the ocean east of the
Philippines on Monday. It hit the southeastern part of Taiwan at
noon Tuesday before reaching Fujian.


Local residents were told in advance by the Fujian Provincial
Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters to get prepared for
the tropical storm.


While making an overall disaster plan, the provincial Party and
government authorities also urged officials at lower levels to
work harder to reduce the potential damages.

Depression in Caribbean Sea could become storm


	   MIAMI (AP) _ A tropical depression over the Caribbean Sea was
expected to strengthen into a tropical storm Thursday.
	   An advisory was in effect for the North Atlantic, Caribbean Sea
and the Gulf of Mexico, forecasters at the National Hurricane
Center said.
	   A large area of disturbed weather changed little in organization
overnight but was beginning to interact with a frontal system,
increasing the system's potential to become a tropical storm.
	   Sustained wind near the center was blowing at about 35 mph and
was likely to reach tropical storm strength of at least 39 mph
Thursday afternoon, forecaster Ed Rappaport said.
	   At 5 a.m. EDT, the center of the poorly organized depression was
located about 380 miles south-southwest of Kingston, Jamaica.
	   A reconnaissance plane was scheduled to fly into the area
Thursday if necessary, Rappaport said.
	   The combination of the depression and a cold front was forecast
to continue producing rain and gusty winds over northeastern Mexico
and portions of the southern Texas coast.

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-05-10 21:36 
 Rough Hurricane Season Predicted  
By RANDOLPH E. SCHMID, Associated Press Writer


   WASHINGTON (AP) -- Hurricane season is fast approaching and the
outlook isn't pretty.


   Federal storm specialists predicted an above-average storm
season Wednesday, calling for stronger, longer-lasting storms this
year, and more of them.


   Hurricane season officially begins June 1, and the outlook is
for 11 tropical storms, seven of which will be hurricanes, three of
them major.


   ''This puts coastal areas and the Caribbean islands at a much
higher risk of experiencing a tropical storm or hurricane,'' said
D. James Baker, head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric
Administration.


   The forecast is similar to last year's, which was followed by a
series of serious storms, including Hurricane Floyd, that caused
massive evacuations along the Southeastern coast and then inundated
North Carolina.


   The La Nina cooling of water in the Pacific Ocean, the same
condition that influenced the 1999 season, remains in place, Baker
said.


   ''For this reason we expect we'll have another major economic
impact on the United States,'' he said.


   ''It's not just about the number'' of storms, added Max
Mayfield, director of the National Hurricane Center in Miami.
''What really counts is where they make landfall and how strong
they are. Just one hurricane over your community makes it a very
bad year.''


   James Lee Witt, director of the Federal Emergency Management
Agency, stressed the importance of having a plan and being prepared
for the storms. He cited community efforts, including Project
Impact, which helps people strengthen their homes against storms of
all types.


   A poll the agency released Wednesday revealed that more than
half of people vulnerable to hurricane damage don't prepare
adequately because they underestimate their risk. Poll takers also
concluded that many do little to protect their homes because they
think the cost is much higher than it actually is. One-third of the
homeowners do not have an evacuation plan.


   More than 1,200 people from Massachusettes to Texas were
questioned for the poll in April and May. The margin of error was
plus or minus 3 percentage points.


   Baker and Witt signed a memorandum pledging to work closely
together to warn people of impending storms and help them prepare.


   ''It doesn't matter how good the forecast is if people don't
plan in advance,'' said Jack Kelly, director of the National
Weather Service.


   Last year's evacuations left thousands of people trapped on
jammed highways for hours and the forecasters said that is a
problem they hope to avoid in the future. Coastal areas subject to
flooding need to be evacuated in storms, but not every place that
merely expects wind damage, they said.


   ''You flee from storm surge, you hide from wind,'' said
Mayfield, calling on people to get storm shutters, build safe rooms
and take other steps to prepare their homes.


   The new outlook from the government forecasters echoes that of
Bill Gray of Colorado State University, one of the few willing to
make long-range storm predictions. For this season he also
predicted 11 named storms.


   Mayfield was picked last week to replace the retired Jerry
Jarrell as director of the hurricane center.


   Also last week a new weather satellite was launched that can be
pressed into service this summer if needed. The $220 million GOES-L
satellite had been delayed a year.


   The forecasters rely on two Geostationary Operational
Environmental Satellites to monitor tropical storms and other
severe weather. The East Coast's GOES-8, however, is a year beyond
its design lifetime. Although still working, it could break down at
any moment. GOES-L is a crucial backup.


   While some climate experts have been blaming the increase in
tropical storms in recent years on global warming, Gray says the
trend is cyclical and not related to warming.


   Asked about this Wednesday, Baker agreed. ''We don't see, at
this point, a link between global warming and tropic

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-09-16 13:27 
 By PAT LESINER  
By PAT LESINER


   TAMPA, Fla. (AP) - As Tropical Storm Gordon threatened to become
a hurricane and strike Florida's Gulf Coast, Gov. Jeb Bush on
Saturday activated emergency response teams.


   State officials said they expect Gordon to be a Category 1
hurricane with winds of 74 to 95 mph when it strikes land anywhere
between Fort Myers and the Panhandle sometime late Sunday.


   Rains of five inches or more are expected and coastal areas
could expect a storm surge, said Joe Myers, the state emergency
management director.


   The National Hurricane Center issued a tropical storm warning
Saturday that covered a 210-mile stretch from Bonita Beach just
south of Fort Myers to the Suwanee River, about 100 miles north of
Tampa.


   Forecasters also issued a hurricane watch for a 400-mile stretch
from Bonita Beach to the Panhandle town of Apalachicola. They said
Gordon could reach hurricane strength by late Saturday.


   A tropical storm warning means a storm with winds of between 39
and 73 mph is expected to hit an area within the next 24 hours. A
hurricane watch means a storm with winds of 74 mph or greater could
hit within the next 36 hours.


   At 10 a.m. EDT, Gordon was located about 355 miles southwest of
Tampa, with winds of 65 mph, 9 mph below hurricane strength. Two to
five inches of rain are expected across portions of South Florida
and the Keys on Saturday, forecasters said.


   Saturday afternoon, counties along central Florida's Gulf Coast
began recommending voluntary evacuation for residents in barrier
islands and coastal or low lying areas.


   Disaster officials in Hernando, Manatee and Pinellas counties
told residents they should start packing, and that shelters would
be opened Saturday evening. Other counties were awaiting later
forecasts before deciding whether of advise their residents to
evacuate.


   The storm is even causing some concern on Florida's Atlantic
coast - at Cape Canaveral, NASA considered Saturday moving space
shuttle Discovery off it's seaside launch pad and into it's hangar.
Discovery is scheduled to blast off on a space-station construction
mission on Oct. 5.


   Gordon's affect is already being felt in Cuba and Mexico.


   Heavy rains of seven to 10 inches affected parts of western Cuba
early Saturday, and heavy rains were reported Friday on Mexico's
Yucatan Peninsula. That caused street flooding in the resort city
of Cancun.


   Meanwhile, tropical storm force winds struck Bermuda on Saturday
as Hurricane Florence passed to the island nation's north, but the
storm is not expected to score a direct hit.


   Winds of 60 mph hit Bermuda early Saturday, but no damage was
reported, the National Hurricane Center said.


   At 7 a.m. EDT, Florence was 125 miles north of Bermuda and was
moving to the northeast at 25 mph. Near its center, it still packed
hurricane force winds of 75 mph, but those are expected to miss the
island, forecasters said.


   Rip currents associated with Florence were blamed for at least
three surf deaths Tuesday in North Carolina.


   Meanwhile, a third disturbance was sighted in the tropics.


   A tropical depression with 35 mph winds was located about 260
miles east of Guadeloupe in the Leeward Islands and was moving west
near 17 mph.


   A tropical storm watch is in effect for the islands of Antigua,
Anguilla, Barbuda, Montserrat, Nevis, St. Kitts, St. Maarten, Saba
and St. Eustatius in the Leeward Islands.


   Wind gusts to tropical storm force in squalls are likely over
parts of the Leewards later Saturday.


   On the Net:


   National Hurricane Center: http://www.nhc.noaa.gov


 AP-ES-09-16-00 1327

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-08-15 15:43 
 Tropical Storm Churns Toward Baja  
By MARK STEVENSON


   MEXICO CITY (AP) -- Tropical Storm Ileana churned past the
southern tip of the Baja California peninsula Tuesday and headed
out to sea, while tropical storm Beryl moved inland, dumping rain
on Texas and northern Mexico as it weakened.


   Ileana doused the Baja resort towns of Los Cabos with rain, but
''nothing too severe,'' said Randy Lehr, the American manager of
the Hacienda Beach Resort in Cabo San Lucas.


   ''It looks like we got lucky, and the storm passed by to the
south,'' Lehr said in a telephone interview. Guests at his hotel
were warned to stay out of the ocean, and some whiled away the time
playing pool.


   The Mexican government declared a hurricane warning for Los
Cabos and areas slightly north, as the storm's center whirled past
about 50 miles south of the peninsula.


   ''There hasn't been any damage so far, and the communications
systems are working fine,'' Baja California state spokesman Juan
Antonio Flores said.


   Ileana, currently with winds of 70 mph, may strengthen to reach
hurricane status, the National Hurricane Center in Miami reported.


   Civil defense authorities in Los Cabos met to monitor the storm
as it brushed by, moving west at about 12 mph. They had previously
reported some outages in local telephone service due to the rains.


   Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Beryl lumbered ashore on Mexico's
northeast coast Tuesday, swirling into land over a sparsely
populated stretch of coast about 110 miles south of the border
cities of Brownsville, Texas, and Matamoros in Mexico.


   The storm quickly weakened to tropical depression status as it
dropped rain over northern Mexico, and the Mexican government
discontinued most storm warnings for coastal areas.


   The hurricane center reported Beryl could cause rainfall of 5 to
10 inches, but predicted the system would probably dissipate by
Wednesday.


   Beryl's winds had fallen to about 35 mph, and the weakening
system was moving roughly west at about 9 mph.


   Residents were evacuated from two low-lying fishing villages in
the Gulf coast state of Tamaulipas and taken to improvised shelters
at schools and a sports complex, the government news agency Notimex
reported.


   The National Weather Service canceled hurricane and tropical
storm warnings for South Texas, where some heavy showers were
reported.


   Farmers in Texas said they hoped the thunderstorms would weaken
the chokehold of a lingering drought. Showers were to continue
throughout the day Tuesday and bring several inches of rain.


   The storms also promised to refill dwindling reservoirs along
the Rio Grande, National Weather Service forecaster Tim Speece
said.


   ''I'm not going to go out on a limb and say it'll end the
drought, period,'' Speece said. ''But it'll definitely have an
effect.''


   ------


   On the Net:


   Hurricane Center: http://www.nhc.noaa.gov


   Hurricane Central:
http://www.weatherpoint.com/hc/home/0,1916,oso,00.html

www.txdps.state.tx.us/dem


   Storm 2000: http://www.gopbi.com/weather/storm

results.content:
1998-11-06 
 Revived Tropical Storm Mitch Strikes Florida 


WASHINGTON, November 5 (Xinhua) -- Tropical Storm Mitch, having
tortured Central America a week ago, lashed Northern Florida of
the United States on Wednesday and Thursday with heavy rain and
strong wind.


The revived Mitch severely struck the Florida Keys with
tornadoes, flipping mobile homes, uprooting trees and cutting power
lines and leading to one highway death.


The island chain had been hit by hurricane Georges, which
destroyed or damaged 4,000 homes in late September.


Hurricane Mitch had weakened significantly after killing at
least 9,000 people during a rampage through Central America last
week. But it revived itself to tropical storm strength while
plowing over the Gulf of Mexico toward Florida.


By Wednesday, several tornadoes had touched down in Key Largo
and one struck in Islamorada. Trailers were turned over and people
were trapped inside.


Farther North, winds gusts reached about 110 kmp near Miami,
where flooding slowed morning commuters. Seven people were treated
for storm-related injuries.


The Coast Guard rescued a man and a woman Wednesday after their
boat sank in large swells off West Palm Beach.


State officials opened three storm shelters Wednesday in the
Keys, housing some 200 people.


A tropical storm warning extended from the Florida Keys north
to Tarpon Springs on Florida's Gulf coast, and north to New Smyrna
Beach on the Atlantic coast.


The storm was expected to move out to sea by this afternoon.

results.content:
1999-04-02 05:14:41 
 usa 
 Deadly Hurricane Season Predicted 


	ORLANDO, Fla. (AP) -- Tropical storms and hurricanes killed  
thousands last year, and a top forecaster says the 1999 Atlantic 
hurricane season could be just as deadly. 


	``The odds strongly favor us entering a new era for storms,''  
William Gray, a Colorado State University weather forecaster, said 
Thursday at the National Hurricane Conference. 


	Gray predicted the Atlantic hurricane season this year could  
match the 14 tropical storms and 10 hurricanes that killed at least 
10,000 people last year, mostly by Hurricane Mitch in Honduras. 


	Cyclical changes making Atlantic waters warmer and saltier are  
behind the upswing in storm activity, Gray said. The same 
conditions have not been seen since the late 1960s. 


	The 1999 season will have 14 named storms and nine hurricanes,  
four of them major, Gray predicted. ``That's a very active 
season,'' he said. 


	Florida could experience severe damage sometime in the near  
future because of the upswing in the number of storms and because 
more people are living in storm-prone areas. 


	``We're going to be seeing a $50 billion-, $70 billion-, $100  
billion-damage storm,'' Gray said. ``Florida is a sitting duck.'' 


	Over the last 30 years, an average of about 10 tropical storms  
have occurred annually, and five or six have reached hurricane 
strength. 


	The hurricane season begins June 1 and lasts through Nov. 30.  


	Gov. Jeb Bush said at the conference that he would work to  
improve hurricane evacuation routes and maintain tougher building 
codes. 


	``We have a responsibility to make sure people can escape when  
they are asked to do so,'' he said. 


	Tropical storm and hurricane names selected for 1999 for the  
Atlantic, Gulf of Mexico and Carribean are Arlene, Bret, Cindy, 
Dennis, Emily, Floyd, Gert, Harvey, Irene, Jose, Katrina, Lenny, 
Maria, Nate, Ophelia, Philippe, Rita, Stan, Tammy, Vince and Wilma.

results.content:
WEATHER 



   NATIONAL FORECAST


   The long dry spell in Florida will end on Thursday as the
moisture associated with Tropical Storm Mitch merges with a
disturbance along a cold front crossing the state. Very heavy rain
will taper off from southwest to northeast across the peninsula.
More than 3 inches of rain will drench the southern and eastern
counties.


   Gusty winds will reach gale force along the southeast coast as
the pressure difference increases between the storm near Florida
and a huge fair-weather system nosing into the Northeast.


   Clouds and a cold rain will spread along the immediate coast,
perhaps as far north as Cape Hatteras. Onshore winds will keep low
clouds over parts of the Piedmont plateau. Sunshine will return to
the central Gulf Coast, but patches of low clouds will persist over
the Tennessee Valley. A brisk wind from the northeast will enhance
the chill.


   While the northeast coast will be mainly sunny and very cool,
patches of low clouds will make the interior dull. A few snow
showers will dust the communities east of lakes Ontario and Huron.
Sunshine and clouds will be mixed over the upper Mississippi
Valley.


   Winds from the southeast will ascend the western Plains leading
to low clouds and patches of drizzle from the Texas panhandle to
southern Montana. A cold front pushing across the northern Rockies
will promote valley showers and mountain snows in the Cascades and
Bitterroots.


   Most of the Southwest and California will be bright, but cooler.
Clouds will be interspersed with sunshine over the central Rockies.
Gusty winds will develop along the central part of the Pacific
Coast.


   Focus: Hybrid Storm


   Tropical Storm Mitch was reborn on Tuesday, as the remnants of
the devastating Atlantic hurricane reorganized in the southern Gulf
of Mexico. On Wednesday, the system began interacting with a
frontal zone to its north. Advancing cool air was causing falling
temperatures in Mitch's wake, while the center of the storm
retained its warm, tropical identity. Now a subtropical storm,
Mitch had evolved into a hybrid between a tropical storm and the
low-pressure systems that roam the middle latitudes. On Thursday,
Tropical Storm Mitch will complete its transition to a
middle-latitude storm after exiting Florida.

results.content:
Tropical storm Celia moves away from Baja California coast


	   MEXICO CITY (AP) _ Tropical storm Celia moved away from the Baja
California coast Saturday and headed out into the Pacific,
prompting Mexican authorities to lift a tropical storm warning for
the southern part of the peninsula.
	   The storm will continue to travel northwest and weaken, the
National Hurricane Center in Miami predicted.
	   Mexico's National Meteorological Service predicted that Celia
may continue to cause strong to moderate rains and heavy waves in
six Mexican Pacific coast states, and recommended that boaters
exercise caution.
	   The storm was about 150 miles (240 kilometers) southwest of Cabo
San Lucas in Baja California, moving northwest and out to sea at
about 17 mph (27 kph) Saturday.
	   The Hurricane Center predicted that the storm will stay on that
track and weaken Sunday and Monday as it moves over cooler waters.
Winds from Celia appeared to extend only about 105 miles (170
kilometers) from the storm's center, as opposed to earlier
estimates of 140 miles (225 kilometers).

results.content:
WEATHER 



   NATIONAL FORECAST &QL;


   On Wednesday, estimates derived from doppler radar indicated
that 6 inches of rain fell across parts of Dade County in southern
Florida as heavy showers and thunderstorms erupted. On Thursday,
clusters of tropical showers and storms again doused the state,
with heavy rains fed by tropical moisture drawn northward by a low
pressure system over the Gulf of Mexico. On Friday, the low, which
will have the potential to develop into a tropical depression, will
stay nearly stationary over the Gulf, all the while drawing
tropical moisture over Florida and again setting the stage for
heavy showers and storms. Tropical showers may reach as far north
as the eastern Carolinas.


   Heavy showers and thunderstorms will skirt the central Gulf
Coast as the low over the Gulf also summons tropical moisture
northwestward. New Orleans will lie in the line of fire of these
storms. Meanwhile, the broad circulation around the low in the Gulf
will draw slightly drier air southwestward into Texas from the Ohio
Valley, thereby limiting showers and storms along the Texas coast.
But dry air will likely not reach southeast Texas, paving the way
for storms near the lower Rio Grande Valley.


   Scattered showers and storms will develop Friday afternoon and
evening from eastern Montana to northwest Minnesota as a burgeoning
area of low pressure teams with fast jet stream winds over
south-central Canada.


   Meanwhile, variable clouds and isolated showers and
thunderstorms will prevail near a stationary front splayed across
the northern Middle Atlantic States.


   Focus: Hot and Dry


   Wednesday marked the 29th consecutive day without measurable
rain at Huntington, W.Va., three days shy of the city's all-time
record dry streak. Not coincidentally, temperatures this week
soared into the 90s, higher than the highest readings of the
summer. With the ground bereft of moisture, little energy from the
sun was spent on evaporation. Instead much of the available energy
from the sun was used to directly heat the ground, which, in turn,
warmed the overlying air. In all likelihood, the bonus energy was
enough to boost temperatures to HuntingtonUs highest levels of
1998.

NEWS STORY 
 2000-09-03 18:22 
 Tropical Storm Ernesto weakens into a depression  


	   MIAMI (AP) - Tropical Storm Ernesto deteriorated into a
depression Sunday afternoon, and was not expected to regenerate,
forecasters said.


   The winds accompanying Ernesto dropped to 35 mph Sunday, below
the tropical storm threshold of 39 mph. Strong vertical winds high
in the atmosphere weakened the storm, said Miles Lawrence,
hurricane specialist with the National Hurricane Center in Miami.


   At 5 p.m. EDT, the depression's poorly organized center was
located near 20.0 north latitude, 59.0 west longitude, or about 300
miles east-northeast of the northern Leeward Islands.


   The storm was about 1,200 miles east-southeast of the Florida
coast and moving west-northwest near 17 mph.


   Ernesto, which formed early Saturday, was the fifth named storm
of the 2000 hurricane season.

results.content:
1999-06-14 03:00:10 
 usa 
 Tropical Storm Spins in Atlantic 


	MIAMI (AP) -- While top winds from the first tropical storm of  
the season dropped to 50 mph overnight, some strengthening was 
possible today as the storm continues spinning over the Atlantic 
Ocean. 


	Tropical Storm Arlene poses no immediate threat to land, at  
least in the next three days, according to the National Hurricane 
Center. 


	``I don't think the East Coast is in the future of this storm,  
but Bermuda -- we'll be looking at that. But it's not a big deal 
right now,'' said hurricane specialist Miles Lawrence. 


	``It's in a weak steering current, so it's not moving much,'' he  
explained. 


	Storm-force winds extended up to 105 miles from the center.  
Arlene was expected to continue moving west today at near 6 mph 
with a gradual turn toward the northwest Tuesday. 


	``It would have a higher chance of surviving if it was going  
east,'' said hurricane forecaster Jack Beven. 


	Storms in this part of the Atlantic often turn toward the  
northeast and die at sea as they enter cooler waters, which 
discourage development. 


	``It's good to start out with something hopefully remaining at  
sea,'' another hurricane forecaster, Richard Pasch, said Sunday.

results.content:
WEATHER 



   NATIONAL FORECAST &QL;


   Rain will end from west to east across Long Island and southern
New England as low pressure accelerates out to sea south of Cape
Cod. Plenty of clouds will linger in the mild, moist air in the
wake of the low from the central Appalachians to the Middle
Atlantic Coast. Some sun will break through the clouds east of the
mountains in Virginia and the Carolinas.


   A narrow band of snow and ice will occur from parts of the
eastern Dakotas to areas near Lake Superior. Moisture-laden air
will be lifted over a shallow cold air mass resulting in locally
heavy freezing rain and sleet in central Minnesota and northern
Wisconsin. Several inches of wet snow will accumulate farther
north. Meanwhile, a broken band of potent thunderstorms will erupt
in the warm air over the central Mississippi valley.


   In the West, a swath of rain will reach central and northern
California. A few showers will dampen the Northwest. The Southwest
will stay dry.


   FOCUS: ENDLESS SEASON


   On Saturday, meteorologists monitoring the southwestern Pacific
issued an alert for the possible formation of a tropical cyclone
near Fiji. In the western Pacific, the season for tropical storms
never ends. The western tropical Pacific has the warmest ocean
water on earth, making it ideal breeding ground for tropical
storms. In the Atlantic, the cool waters of spring are inhospitable
to tropical storms. Indeed, April is the only month when no
tropical storm has been detected in the Atlantic.

Tropical storm strengethens off Mexico's Pacific coast


	   MEXICO CITY (AP) _ A tropical storm that formed off of Mexico's
Pacific coast is expected to become a hurricane but was heading
west and away from land, the U.S. National Hurricane Center
reported.
	   Tropical storm Estelle was over 300 miles (483 kilometers) south
of Manzanillo, Mexico at 11:00 a.m. EDT (1500 GMT), with sustained
winds of nearly 70 mph (113 kph). It was heading west at about 9
mph (14 kph).
	   Hurricanes have minimum sustained wind speeds of 74 mph (119
kph).
	   Forecasters said it Estelle would probably grow to hurricane
force by Friday, but early predictions of the track indicated it
was unlikely to hit land.
	   Meanwhile, forecasters at the National Hurricane Center in Miami
said Friday that tropical Storm Alex poses an increasing threat to
Puerto Rico and other Caribbean islands but is weakening.
	   The storm doesn't have a chance to develop in the short term as
it advances with 50 mph (80 kph) winds toward the northeastern
Caribbean Sea, center director Jerry Jarrell said Friday.
	   ``(So) it's a little bit of a threat to Puerto Rico and the
Virgin Islands ... with a weaker storm,'' he said.
	   At 1500 GMT Friday, Alex was located near 15.5 north latitude,
49.5 west longitude, or about 725 miles (1,166 kilometers) east of
the Leeward Islands in the eastern Caribbean.
	   The storm is expected to continue moving west near 12 mph (19
kph) with top sustained winds of about 50 mph (80 kph), but
forecasters said it could begin a gradual turn to the
west-northwest.

results.content:
&HT;   



   WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. _ Hurricane forecasters, stung by
criticism that people were caught off guard when Irene veered from
its most likely path and moved through coastal South Florida,
stressed again Tuesday the storm's track was within a probable
strike zone and would have dumped torrential rains on Palm Beach
County and the Treasure Coast regardless of the change in
direction.


   The National Hurricane Center near Miami said a tropical storm
warning for the region was appropriate because no hurricane-force
winds were recorded anywhere in the three counties.


   ``I can see why things are confusing to people,'' center
director Jerry Jarrell said. ``We had a hurricane. There's no
question about it. But you and I didn't get hurricane conditions.
We got tropical storm conditions.''


   Palm Beach County's emergency management director, Bill O'Brien,
was more critical of himself than the hurricane center on Tuesday,
saying his office opened shelters for people who didn't feel
comfortable in their homes but in hindsight, should have encouraged
mobile home evacuations.


   ``I know those guys do the very best they can,'' O'Brien said of
the hurricane center.


   Jarrell said the storm's path shifted in those crucial hours on
Friday because its eye reformed several times over land, each time
moving to the east _ a phenomenon forecasters can't explain. He
said such events occurred last year in several storms in the Gulf
of Mexico, with the eye jumping as much as 75 miles over to the
east. Jarrell said that's why tracking charts showed a steady track
to the northeast even as the center continued to forecast a
northern path.


   ``If you're connecting the dots, it was'' heading north, Jarrell
said. ``But if you're watching the eye, you're seeing it reform.''


   Jarrell said that the strongest rains were farther east of
center, and had the storm stayed on a path west of Lake Okeechobee,
coastal Palm Beach County and the Treasure Coast would have
received even more rain.


   Jarrell also said a fire last month inside a weather computer in
Maryland may have contributed to the less-than-exact forecast. The
center made only two models a day instead of four, while other
agencies' computers were available to do the other two models.
Jarrell said that may have hampered the forecasting but it was
early too say.


   The center also suggested on Tuesday that employers consider
sending employees home in a tropical storm warning instead of a
hurricane warning.


   ``It's just a meteorological distinction between 73 mph as a
tropical storm and 74 mph as a hurricane,'' National Hurricane
Center spokesman Frank Lepore said.


   ``I guess that's natural,'' O'Brien said. ``People hear
`hurricane' and they think anything from what we saw to Andrew. We
have some strong storms on a routine basis in the summer that have
tropical storm force winds.''


   Gary Hines, senior vice president of the Business Development
Board of Palm Beach County, said the idea of companies sending
workers home in tropical storm warnings is ``worth the weather
service presenting it to employers.''


   Jarrell said the center doesn't want to get into the business of
deciding when to open shelters, evacuate or order employees home.


   ``Emergency management folks feel that is not our business,''
Jarrell said. ``We agree with that.''


   Residents who suffered storm damage will base their insurance
claims, and deductibles, on a hurricane strike, said Don Pride,
spokesman for the Florida Department of Insurance.


   Eliot Kleinberg writes for the Palm Beach Post, West Palm Beach,
Fla. E-mail: eliotkleinberg(at)pbpost.com


   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers


   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service

1998-08-04 
 Tropical Storm Expected to Hit East China on Wednesday 


BEIJING, August 4 (Xinhua) -- The second tropical storm of this
year is expected to hit Fujian, a coastal province in east China,
on Wednesday morning, the state meteorological bureau reported
today.


The storm should move northward to Jiangxi and Anhui provinces,
putting heavy pressure on flood-affected areas along the middle
and lower reaches of the Yangtze River.


A typhoon formed east of the Philippines at 2 p.m. (Beijing
Time) Monday and turned into a tropical storm at 8 p.m. the same
day.


The storm's center was 150 kilometers (km) south of Hengchun in
Taiwan at 5 a.m. today with gale-force winds. It is moving
northwest at a speed of 20 km per hour.


The storm is expected to bring torrential rains to coastal
Fujian and Zhejiang provinces. The southern part of north China,
the Yellow River and Huaihe River Valley, Shandong Province and
the Liaodong Peninsula in Liaoning Province will also be
affected.

results.content:
Mitch weakens to tropical storm, but 31 aboard missing boat


	   LA LIMA, Honduras (AP) _ A yacht with 31 people aboard was
missing Thursday in the storm-roiled Caribbean, where Hurricane
Mitch killed 32 people before being downgraded to a tropical storm.
	   A U.S. Coast Guard airplane was searching for the boat, while
storm-driven floodwaters continued to rise on shore, cutting some
Central American communities off from food, water and medicine.
	   Mitch, which on Tuesday ranked among the century's most powerful
storms, weakened to a tropical storm on Thursday as it moved
slightly inland over Honduras.
	   At 2100 GMT, sustained winds were only 60 mph (95 kph), down
from 180 mph (290 kph) early Tuesday, though the storm was still
tearing into the same coastline and tourist islands it had been
lashing for three days.
	   Incessant rain along the coast has flooded at least 50 rivers in
Honduras, knocking out bridges and highways and putting many towns
under water. More than 150,000 people were forced to seek higher
ground in the region, including Honduras, Nicaragua, Belize and
Mexico.

1999-06-14 12:00:27 
 usa 
 Tropical Storm Spins in Atlantic 


	MIAMI (AP) -- A tropical storm watch was issued for Bermuda as  
Tropical Storm Arlene headed westward today across the Atlantic. 


	Arlene, the first storm of the Atlantic season, saw its top  
sustained winds drop to 50 mph overnight, with no significant 
change in strength expected through Tuesday. 


	Forecasters had said the storm might threaten Bermuda at some  
point, but is expected to curve away into the open ocean before 
reaching the United States. 


	``I don't think the (U.S.) East Coast is in the future of this  
storm,'' said National Hurricane Center specialist Miles Lawrence. 


	At 2 p.m. EDT, Arlene's center was about 280 miles southeast of  
Bermuda. Storm-force winds extended up to 115 miles from the 
center. Arlene was expected to continue moving west-northwest at 
near 6 mph with a gradual turn toward the northwest tonight and 
Tuesday. 


	Storms in this part of the Atlantic often eventually turn toward  
the northeast and die at sea as they enter cooler waters, which 
discourage development. 


	``It's good to start out with something hopefully remaining at  
sea,'' another hurricane forecaster, Richard Pasch, said Sunday. 


	Colorado State University professor William Gray, who pioneered  
annual hurricane forecasting, is predicting 14 named storms this 
season, the same as last year.

Tropical storm Celia moves away from Baja California coast


	   MEXICO CITY (AP) _ Tropical storm Celia moved away from the Baja
California coast Saturday and headed out into the Pacific,
prompting Mexican authorities to lift a tropical storm warning for
the southern part of the peninsula.
	   The storm will continue to travel out to sea and weaken, the
National Hurricane Center in Miami predicted, while noting that
``rough seas and gusty winds are likely to persist over adjacent
marine areas for the next day or two.''
	   Celia's winds weakened to about 50 mph (80 kph) by Saturday,
when the storm was located about 200 miles (320 kilometers) west of
Cabo San Lucas, Baja California, moving in a generally western
direction at about 14 mph (22 kph).
	   The ports of Cabo San Lucas and San Jose del Cabo were closed to
sea traffic as a result of the 12-foot (3.6-meter) waves kicked up
by the storm, local media reported.

results.content:
2000-08-29 
 Tropical Storm Sweeps Closer to Zhejiang 


HANGZHOU, August 29 (Xinhua) -- A tropical storm whirled close
to east China's Zhejiang Province today, promoting local
authorities to move people to safer areas and prepare to make sure
possible losses are at a minimum.


Sources from the Zhejiang Provincial Meteorological Station
said that the Prapiroon developed into a tropical storm at 8 p.m.
last night and was centered in the sea area 23.3 degrees north
latitude and 125.6 degrees east longitude or some 800 kilometers
southeast of Wenzhou City.


The sources said the tropical storm, with a whole gale near its
center, is expected to enter the East China Sea this afternoon and
land in central and northern coastal Zhejiang Wednesday evening.


Starting today, fresh gale and whole gale winds are expected to
lash Zhejiang's sea areas, and from this evening to Wednesday,
rainstorms and torrential rains are expected in the province's
coastal areas.


Local concerned departments have been warned to keep on alert
and make preparations against possible floods, landslides and
other disasters.

results.content:
WEATHER 



   NATIONAL FORECAST


   A surge of cooler, less humid air will reach the eastern Great
Lakes as a cold front pushes off the New England coast early
Wednesday. Showers and a few gusty thunderstorms will mark the
front's passage in the Northeast, but skies will become sunny from
Michigan to western Pennsylvania as drier air arrives on fresh
breezes from the northwest.


   High pressure over Alabama will promote sultry conditions across
the South. A few thundershowers will form in Florida and near the
southern Appalachians. The remnants of Topical Storm Beryl will
produce heavy showers from the Rio Grande Valley into northern
Mexico.


   A cluster of thunderstorms will drench the Dakotas and Minnesota
as hot, humid air moves north. Showers will reach into the Middle
West later on. Afternoon storms will develop over the Rockies, but
the Northwest will be bright, pleasant and a bit cooler.


   FOCUS: THE BERYL PERIL


   Tropical Storm Beryl made landfall before daybreak Tuesday along
a desolate part of the northeast Mexico coast. The storm quickly
lost its wind circulation, but torrential rains persisted along the
coast. Even though Beryl is nothing more than a weak low pressure
system, its rich supply of tropical moisture continues to pose a
threat to the steep terrain of the Sierra Madre Oriental. Flash
flooding from dying tropical storms is an infamous hazard. On July
25-26, 1979, the remnants of Tropical Storm Claudette dropped 43
inches of rain on Alvin, Texas.

results.content:
1999-09-21 04:20:12 
 usa 
 Tropical Storm Churns Closer to Fla. 


	CLEARWATER, Fla. (AP) -- An unsettled Tropical Storm Harvey bore  
down on southern Florida today with 50 mph winds and heavy rain, 
prompting school closures and an emergency declaration from the 
governor. 


	Five to 10 inches of rain were expected from the storm forecast  
to come ashore near Naples, 150 miles south of Clearwater, by 
tonight. 


	Harvey weakened slightly and turned to the southeast early today  
as tropical storm warnings were posted for southern Florida, 
including the Keys island chain. Earlier predictions had the storm 
making landfall near Tampa, on Florida's western coast. 


	At 5 a.m., Harvey was centered about 100 miles southwest of Fort  
Myers and moving to the southeast at 10 mph. Tropical storm force 
winds of at least 39 mph extended out some 115 miles. 


	The storm was expected to cross Florida and stay offshore as it  
heads north along the East Coast. 


	``The center is not really well defined. It's just kind of a  
raggedy system,'' said Stephen Baig, oceanographer at the National 
Hurricane Center in Miami. ``Essentially, the southern peninsula of 
Florida is going to get lots of rain and gusts.'' 


	Gov. Jeb Bush on Monday declared a state of emergency for 56 of  
67 counties in anticipation of the storm. Harvey could produce 
storm surge flooding of up to 6 feet above normal in some places. 


	But most voluntary evacuations called for in the Tampa area --  
advising people living in mobile homes, recreational vehicles, 
coastal and low-lying areas to move -- were lifted today. 


	``It's been pretty quiet up here,'' said John Brill, spokesman  
for the Hillsborough County Emergency Management Center. ``It 
turned toward the south and we haven't had a whole lot of action up 
here.'' 


	Meanwhile, Bermuda's government issued a hurricane warning  
Monday as Gert moved within 170 miles of the island with top winds 
of 110 mph.

Tropical Storm Alex weakens, but may veer closer to Caribbean


	   MIAMI (AP) _ Tropical Storm Alex has weakened, posing only a
minimal threat to Puerto Rico and other Caribbean islands, although
it could come closer to land than earlier thought.
	   ``The good news is that the storm is falling apart,'' Jerry
Jarrell, director of the U.S. National Hurricane Center, said
Friday.
	   But, he said, the storm is centered farther south than had been
expected, a course that may bring it closer to the islands.
	   At 11 p.m. EDT Friday (0300 GMT Saturday), Alex was located near
16.1 north latitude, 52.1 west longitude, or about 575 miles (925
kilometers) east of the Leeward Islands in the eastern Caribbean.
	   The storm's wind speed decreased to near 40 mph (64 kph). It is
moving west at about 13 mph (21 kph). Forecasters say that although
they said Thursday that they expected Alex to reach hurricane
status within two days, strong southerly upper-level winds hit the
storm, weakening it.
	   Forecasters said Alex could be downgraded to a tropical
depression Friday night or Saturday.

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-09-15 22:16 
 Florence to pass by Bermuda; depressions in Gulf, Atlantic  
AP Photo FLAC101


   MIAMI (AP) - Warnings went up Friday on Bermuda as Tropical
Storm Florence moved toward the Atlantic island and away from the
southeastern United States.


   Meanwhile, tropical depressions in the Gulf of Mexico and the
Atlantic Ocean east of the Leeward Islands were on the verge of
becoming the sixth and seventh named storms of the Atlantic
hurricane season.


   The first depression slid into warm, storm-generating waters in
the southern Gulf of Mexico. Forecasters said it could become
Tropical Storm Gordon as early as Friday evening, menacing the Gulf
coast anywhere along U.S. shores in three days' time.


   Nearly 500 miles east of the Caribbean's Leeward Islands, a
depression was close to tropical storm strength, heading on a
largely westerly track, poised to become Helene.


   Bermuda was preparing for heavy rains and surf-churning winds of
45 mph or more by late Friday as Florence was expected to cross
just west of the island before dawn Saturday.


   At 8 p.m. EDT, Florence's maximum sustained winds were up to
near 70 mph and centered near latitude 30.8 north, longitude 67.5
west, or about 200 miles west- southwest of Bermuda. Some
strengthening was expected overnight, with the possibility Florence
again might become a hurricane.


   Florence was moving east-northeast at about 20 mph, and was
expected to make a gradual turn to the northeast with an increase
in forward speed during the next few days and shoot toward the open
Atlantic, forecasters said.


   ''Florence is ... no threat to the United States. It should pass
within 60 miles of Bermuda overnight,'' according to Eric Blake, a
meteorologist with the National Hurricane Center in Miami.
''Bermuda should feel heavy rain, high winds and dangerous surf.''


   In Hamilton, Bermuda, residents were taking a relaxed attitude,
despite an earlier warning from Public Safety Minister Paula Cox.


   ''We should be vigilant now. We should keep on the alert for
other advisories, particularly warnings during high surf
conditions,'' Cox said.


   Bank worker Killian Morrisey, though, summed up the mood on the
streets.


   ''We had Hurricane Gert last year and not much happened. I am
not stocking up on provisions. And if anything happens, I am not
going to die in a couple of days.''


   And along Front Street, Hamilton's main drag, none of the shops
were boarded up Friday afternoon.


   The depression which formed Thursday in the extreme western
Caribbean Sea, crossed Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula during the night
and moved into warm waters in the southern Gulf.


   At 5 p.m. EDT, the depression was centered near 21.7 north
latitude, 88.0 west longitude, over the north coast of the Yucatan
peninsula. The depression was meandering for hours Friday, but was
expected to shift slowly toward the north-northwest through the
night.


   It had top sustained winds of 35 mph.


   ''We actually predict that one will become a tropical storm
first - that would be Gordon,'' Blake said. ''We expect it in the
Gulf of Mexico to move to the north-northwest and still be in the
Gulf in 72 hours.''


   Depressions become named tropical storms once their top
sustained winds reach 39 mph; tropical storms become hurricanes
once their top sustained winds hit 74 mph.


   At 5 p.m. EDT, the third system was centered near 15.6 north
latitude, 53.5 west longitude, or about 470 miles east of the
Leeward Islands. It was expected to move west-northwest at about 16
mph well into Saturday.


   The Atlantic system also had top winds of 35 mph and was
expected to become a tropical storm before reaching the Leeward
Islands.


   ''We expect that one to move westward and to affect the Leeward
Islands within the next 36 hours,'' said Blake. ''We do anticipate
that it will become Tropical Storm Helene before the system reaches
that point.

Republic, so its way too far away now to speculate on any possible

results.content:
1996-07-28 
 Tropical Storms Kill At Least 74 in Southeast Asia 


HANOI, July 28 (Xinhua) -- Two tropical storms hitting
Southeast Asia in the past week have killed at least 74 people in
the region, most of them in Vietnam and the Philippines.


In Vietnam, tropical storm Frankie killed 41 people, injured
224 others and caused property damage worth some 91 million
U.S. dollars, the Vietnam News Agency said.


Most of the casualties and damage in the country were in three
coastal provinces -- Thai Binh, Nam Ha and Ninh Binh, located on
either side of the mouth of the Red River.


In the Philippines, typhoon Gloria killed 30 people and caused
at least 37.4 million dollars in property damage, relief officials
said. Eight more people were reported missing.


Gloria also killed three people in China's Taiwan province
before lashing onto the country's southeast coast province of
Fujian and downgraded to a tropical storm.


Among the dead were a 5-year-old girl killed by a falling tree,
a motorcyclist drowned after being blown into a creek, and a
villager who fell from his roof while making repairs.

results.content:
Forecasters say Alex is barely a tropical storm


	   MIAMI (AP) _ Alex was barely strong enough to be considered a
tropical storm Saturday, but it was moving closer to some Caribbean
islands, forecasters at the National Hurricane Center said.
	   At 11 a.m. (1500 GMT) Saturday, the storm's poorly organized
center was near 17.5 north latitude, 55 west latitude.
	   It was about 370 miles (600 kilometers) east of the Leeward
Islands, and moving west northwest at about 15 mph (24 kph).
	   Maximum winds were near 40 mph. (65 kph).
	   Meanwhile, Hurricane Estelle gained strength far off the Mexican
Pacific coast on Saturday, posing little risk to land but bringing
light rain to western Mexico.
	   The U.S. Hurricane Center said Estelle was about 555 miles (890
kilometers) south-southwest of the tip of the Baja California
Peninsula and moving west at 15 mph (24 kph), and churning maximum
sustained winds of 110 mph (177 kph).
	   Estelle was expected to continuing gaining strength over the
next day or so, until it moves over cooler waters, the center said.
	   Little change was expected in Alex's strength, but the weather
service said it would send a plane into the storm Saturday
afternoon to determine whether it could be downgraded to a tropical
depression.
	   Meanwhile, a large tropical wave in the central tropical
Atlantic Ocean was moving westward at 15 mph (24 kph).
	   Slow development of the system was possible during the next day
or two, forecasters said.

results.content:
WEATHER 



   NATIONAL FORECAST


   Finally, after an entire week of tropical storm warnings and
hurricane watches, the North Carolina Coast will be dry and
tranquil Monday, though low clouds may persist along the Outer
Banks. A tropical depression, the remnants of Dennis, will move
north along the western slopes of the Appalachians from near
Charleston, W.Va., early Monday to Bradford, Pa., Monday night.
This will cause the steadiest rain to fall into the upper Ohio
River Basin. Up to four inches may accumulate in northern West
Virginia and western Pennsylvania.


   An air flow from the southeast at the surface to 30,000 feet
will draw moist, tropical air from the western Atlantic into the
Middle Atlantic and New England states. Showers and scattered
thunderstorms will drench some sections with more than an inch of
rain and miss others as they move toward the northwest. Maine
should be quite warm with increasing clouds.


   High pressure over the Middle West will promote very warm but
dry conditions from the Upper Plains to the Gulf states. The
merging of a weak tropical wave from the western Gulf of Mexico
with a jet stream disturbance in the Red River Valley will bring
numerous thunderstorms to eastern Texas, Oklahoma and sections of
Louisiana and Arkansas. Sea breezes will cause a few storms near
the eastern Gulf Coast.


   Cooler air will surge into the Northwest behind a front in the
northern Rockies. Offshore winds will keep Oregon and the northern
California coast on the sunny side. Fog will be stubborn to leave
coastal valleys of southern California. &QL;


   FOCUS: Tropical Environs


   In the middle of last week, there was serious discussion that
Dennis had lost its tropical characteristics as record cool air was
swept into its circulation even as it stalled off the coast. But
when Dennis finally made landfall, there was little question that
it had stayed a tropical storm. Indeed, readings in Kentucky, west
of the storm, and in Vermont, well to the north, reached the lower
90s. Burlington rose to 93 degrees, just shy of its all-time
September record. Certainly, Dennis had brought part of the tropics
to those on the periphery of its circulation.

Though Hurricane Dennis was downgraded to a tropical storm as it slowed off the East Coast this week, i
results.content:
WEATHER 



   Thursday afternoon, tropical-storm warnings remained in effect
for the Middle Atlantic Coast from Cape Lookout, N.C., to Cape
Charles Light, Va., as former Hurricane Dennis wobbled slowly over
the Atlantic about 100 miles southeast of Cape Hatteras, N.C.


   Friday, Tropical Storm Dennis will continue to flounder off the
Carolina coast as it sends bands of gusty showers toward shore.
Large ocean swells will batter the coast, with storm-surge flooding
up to 4 feet possible around times of high tide.


   Farther north, some of the mid- to upper-level moisture
associated with Tropical Storm Dennis will stream inland into
southeast Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and, perhaps parts of southeast
New York, mainly in the form of cirrus and altostratus clouds.


   Clusters of thunderstorms will flare over parts of the western
Gulf States as an upper-level low pressure system stalls over
Louisiana. Farther north, isolated but potent thunderstorms will
erupt over parts of the central Rockies from southeast Wyoming to
northeast Colorado as moist winds from the southeast are forced to
rise up the sloping terrain.


   Severe weather, including isolated tornadoes, is possible.
Storms will migrate east onto the high plains of western Kansas and
Nebraska. Meanwhile, scattered showers and thunderstorms will form
along a front from eastern South Dakota to Minnesota.


   A chilly rain with temperatures in the upper 40s to 50s will
again make for a rather raw day over parts of Montana.


   FOCUS: TENACIOUS DENNIS


   Hurricanes that stall over the ocean usually perish by their own
hand. Like an agitating washing machine, winds associated with a
stalled hurricane continually stir underlying seas. Over time, cool
water from the depths rises to replace warm surface water that is
mixed downward by stirring winds. The surfacing of cool water is
the kiss of death for a stalled tropical system. Though Hurricane
Dennis was downgraded to a tropical storm as it slowed off the East
Coast this week, it has maintained its strength because it stalled
over the persistently warm Gulf Stream ocean current.

results.content:
1999-08-26 03:30:09 
 usa 
 Tropical Storm Upgraded to Hurricane 


	NASSAU, Bahamas (AP) -- Hurricane Dennis crept toward the Bahamas  
and the Carolinas early today, but forecasters expected a weather 
system sweeping east across the United States to help protect much 
of the South. 


	``Our forecast will take the storm near or just east of the  
Bahamas and possibly toward the Carolinas,'' said hurricane 
specialist Jack Beven of the National Hurricane Center in Miami. 


	Dennis was upgraded to a hurricane with 75 mph winds late  
Wednesday off the southern Bahamas. 


	Beven said Dennis might spin out to sea, but it was too early to  
predict. He urged people on the southeast coast of the United 
States, primarily North and South Carolina, to closely monitor 
Dennis. 


	At 5 a.m. EDT, Dennis was about 275 miles east-southeast of  
Nassau. The hurricane was moving west-northwest around 5 mph. 


	With top winds of 75 mph, Dennis was barely a hurricane, but  
forecasters predicted the storm would strengthen. Hurricane force 
winds extended 45 miles from its center. 


	The tropical storm warning for the southeastern Bahamas and  
Turks and Caicos Islands was discontinued. But a tropical storm 
warning remained in effect for the rest of the Bahamas. 


	Even before Dennis reached hurricane strength, North Carolinians  
began taking precautions. 


	``We have some water stockpiled,'' said Scott Garner, assistant  
fire marshal in Brunswick County. 


	Forecasters had been watching the interaction between Tropical  
Storm Emily and Cindy, upgraded to a hurricane again late 
Wednesday. 


	``Cindy has taken a bit more of a turn to the north than we  
expected,'' Beven said, explaining that the storms were now too far 
apart to affect one another. 


	While Cindy was no threat to land, forecasters cautioned people  
in the Lesser Antilles of the eastern Caribbean to keep an eye on 
Emily. 


	At 5 a.m. EDT, Emily was about 300 miles east of Martinique. The  
small storm was traveling northwest at about 7 mph. Its top winds 
were 45 mph, and forecasters said slight strengthening was possible 
today.

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-08-09 23:27 
 Alberto Called a Hurricane Again  
By CATHERINE WILSON


   MIAMI (AP) -- Alberto, the first named tropical storm of the
season, returned to hurricane strength deep in the Atlantic Ocean
on Wednesday, but forecasters predicted it would stay far from
land.


   Forecasters also were tracking a small system east of Florida
that they said could develop into a tropical storm.


   Alberto intensified during the day as it moved on a
northwesterly course. It is expected to swing northward later in
the week and pass well east of Bermuda, National Hurricane Center
forecasters said.


   With 75 mph winds, Alberto was just over the 74 mph threshold
when a tropical storm becomes a hurricane. It had reached 85 mph on
Monday.


   At 10 p.m. EDT, the hurricane's center was about 815 miles
southeast of Bermuda. It was moving northwest at about 23 mph.


   Meanwhile, forecasters were puzzled by a small tropical
depression about 110 miles east of Cape Canaveral, off central
Florida's coast.


   One computer model predicted a hurricane would form, but the
center's three-day forecast keeps the system nameless, meaning
steady winds below 39 mph. If the system's winds reach 39 mph, it
will be classified as a tropical storm and named Beryl.


   At 11 p.m., the depression was edging west, with steady winds
near 35 mph.


   The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June through November,
peaking around Labor Day.


   ------


   On the Net: http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/


 AP-NY-08-09-00 2327

results.content:
WEATHER 



   NATIONAL FORECAST &QL;


   A winter storm warning was issued Friday for the north-central
mountains of Colorado as another in a series of powerful Pacific
disturbances approached from the Great Basin. On Saturday, the
formidable system will inflict stormy weather on parts of the
Midwest.


   Moderate to heavy rains will douse the region from the central
Plains to the southwest Great Lakes region as the system lifts
moist air streaming north from the Gulf of Mexico. Rainfalls in
excess of an inch are possible across eastern Nebraska, South
Dakota, Iowa, southern Minnesota and southern Wisconsin by Saturday
night.


   Thunderstorms will erupt across a region bounded by the middle
Mississippi, lower Ohio and Tennessee Valley as humid air from the
Gulf is vigorously lifted by a cold front associated with the
system. Some of the thunderstorms will reach severe levels,
spawning large hail, damaging straight-line winds and tornadoes. As
with most stormy outbreaks, severe weather will affect only a very
small percentage of the region at risk.


   In the wake of the system, winds gusting to 60 mph or more will
buffet the foothills and high plains east of the Front Range of the
central Rockies.


   Meanwhile, moderate to locally heavy rains will develop from
southwest Oregon to northern and central California as yet another
Pacific disturbance drops southeastward along the coast. The
heaviest rains will likely fall along the Coastal Range.


   After a cloudy start, the sky over the Northeast Seaboard will
brighten with the onset on dry, cool breezes from the northwest. &QL;


   Focus: April in the Tropics


   No sooner had Tropical Storm Jacob been christened by the Joint
Typhoon Warning Center in Guam on Thursday, the system was
downgraded to a depression as it suddenly lost power over the
western Pacific. The system lasted six hours as a tropical storm.


   Tropical storms are not unusual in April in the western Pacific,
given the year-long warmth of tropical seas. In contrast, April is
the only month of the year that a tropical storm has never been
observed over the Atlantic. Sea-surface temperatures reach a nadir
in April, while fast, high-altitude winds from the west are very
disruptive.

results.content:
1999-09-10 15:00:15 
 usa 
 No Chances Taken With Floyd 


	THE VALLEY, Anguilla (AP) -- Islanders boarded up houses and  
stocked up on emergency supplies Friday, taking no chances as 
Tropical Storm Floyd strengthened into a hurricane, even though 
forecasters said it was unlikely to hit land soon. 


	``In the next few days we expect it to organize and strengthen  
and it could eventually become a major hurricane,'' said 
meteorologist Todd Kimberlain of the National Hurricane Center in 
Miami. 


	The hurricane did not pose any immediate threat to the United  
States. At 5 p.m. EDT, Floyd was moving farther away from land, 
centered about 250 miles northeast of Anguilla in the eastern 
Caribbean. It was expected to continue moving northwest at near 12 
mph through the day. 


	Hurricane force winds extended about 70 miles from the storm's  
center, and tropical storm force winds extended another 175 miles. 


	Floyd was north of the Leeward Islands, the U.S. and British  
Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico, but some islands could experience 
tropical storm conditions, forecasters said. 


	The governments of Antigua, Barbuda, Anguilla, Dutch St.  
Maarten, French St. Martin and St. Barthelemy issued tropical storm 
watches. 


	In Anguilla, the government closed schools and residents put up  
hurricane shutters despite sunny skies, in case the storm veered in 
their direction. Ports and airports remained open. 


	``Based on what I saw, the people are taking this thing serious.  
They are shopping mostly for dry foods, and batteries, which are 
essential during a hurricane,'' said Lee Brooks, manager of a 
supermarket in The Valley, capital of the British island. 


	The weather also was mild in Barbuda, with light rain in the  
morning but clear skies later, said hotel worker Ruth Henry. 
Schools and businesses remained open. 


	``All along we were told Floyd wouldn't be of any consequence to  
us,'' Henry said. 


	It was too early to tell if the storm would threaten the  
Bahamas, which lie far north of other Caribbean islands, Kimberlain 
said. Floyd is expected to be east of the Bahamas in about three 
days, he said.

results.content:
Tropical storm strengethens off Mexico's Pacific coast


	   MEXICO CITY (AP) _ A tropical storm that formed off of Mexico's
Pacific coast is expected to become a hurricane but was heading
west and away from land, the U.S. National Hurricane Center
reported.
	   Tropical storm Estelle was over 300 miles (483 kilometers) south
of Manzanillo, Mexico at 11:00 a.m. EDT (1500 GMT), with sustained
winds of nearly 70 mph (113 kph). It was heading west at about 9
mph (14 kph).
	   Hurricanes have minimum sustained wind speeds of 74 mph (119
kph).
	   Forecasters said it Estelle would probably grow to hurricane
force by Friday, but early predictions of the track indicated it
was unlikely to hit land.
	   Meanwhile, U.S. forecasters predicted that another tropical
storm, Alex, would strengthen slowly over the weekend.
	   ``During the next two or three days, we expect gradual
strengthening and probably not a direct hit to any land area during
that period,'' Ed Rappaport, a specialist with the National
Hurricane Center in Florida, said late Thursday.
	   At 5 a.m. EDT (0900 GMT) Friday, Alex was located near 16.2
north latitude, 48.9 west longitude. It was about 800 miles (1,287
kilometers) east of the Leeward Islands in the eastern Caribbean.
	   The storm was moving west-northwest near 13 mph (20 kph) with
top sustained winds of 50 mph (80 kph). Those figures were the same
late Thursday and weren't expected to change much Friday _ though
forecasters said Alex might reach hurricane strength within a
couple of days.
