results.content:
WEATHER 



   NATIONAL FORECAST


   Ocean clouds, showers and a few thunderstorms associated with a
low pressure system off the Middle Atlantic seaboard will move
unconventionally westward Saturday, affecting coastal areas from
Delaware to northern North Carolina. The unusual direction of the
low will result from the eastward-steering winds of the jet stream
almost completely receding over Canada.


   With languid steering winds over the Deep South, widely
separated showers and thunderstorms will move slowly, setting the
stage for protracted heavy rains over parts of Florida, Georgia,
South Carolina, Alabama and Mississippi. Flash flooding is possible
in spots. Isolated, slow-moving storms will also occur over parts
of Louisiana and eastern Texas, mainly just inland from the Gulf
Coast, where the leading edge of the sea breeze wedges under and
lifts humid air.


   Isolated but potent thunderstorms will develop over high ground
from eastern Colorado to eastern New Mexico and the panhandle of
northwest Texas as weak but moist winds from the east are forced to
ascend the sloping terrain. A few of these storms could produce
large hail and damaging winds.


   Without robust steering winds, a front will only waver across
the Middle West from the central Plains to the western Great Lakes.
Clusters of showers and thunderstorms, a few severe and some with
heavy rain, will develop in the warm, humid air along and just
ahead of the front.


   Meanwhile, onshore breezes will keep much of the Northeast
seaboard cool to mild while the interior warms dramatically.


   Focus: Tropical Catalysts


   Weak fronts whose southern ends touch the tropical Atlantic
Ocean are breeding grounds for tropical storms during the early
stages of hurricane season. Surface winds from the southeast ahead
of a front and winds from the northeast behind a front provide a
circulation of air over warm water _ a recipe that can lead to the
spin-up of storms. As summer progresses, fronts no longer reach the
tropics. Instead, disturbances moving west from Africa serve as
catalysts for tropical storms. Near November, African disturbances
fade and fronts reappear to spawn the last storms of the season.

results.content:
2000-09-11 
 Tropical Storm Hits Vietnam's Central Province 


HANOI, September 11 (Xinhua) -- Tropical storm Wukong hit
Vietnam's central province of Ha Tinh Sunday, killing at least one
person and injuring 14 others, local Daily Vietnam News reported
Monday.


The storm with heavy rains and strong winds measuring between
eight and nine on the Beaufort scale (62-82 kilometers per hour)
also left 3,000 houses destroyed, the roofs of 5,000 others blown
away and 11,000 hectares of rice submerged.


Torrential downpours and tidal waves also breached several
kilometers of sea dykes and left two communes in Thanh Ha District
isolated.


At 4 p.m. Sunday, Wukong, the 4th storm to threaten the country
this season, weakened into a tropical low pressure and headed in a
westerly direction toward the Vietnam-Laos border, the newspaper
said.

results.content:
1999-09-09 
 Tropical Storm Floyd Forms in Atlantic 


WASHINGTON, September 8 (Xinhua) -- Tropical Storm Floyd formed
in the Atlantic Ocean hundreds of kilometers east of the Caribbean
Wednesday with ominous potential, hurricane forecasters said.


On Wednesday morning, the center of Floyd was located about
1,280 kilometers (800 miles) east of the Leeward Islands at
latitude 15.6 north, longitude 49.1 west, the U.S. National
Hurricane Center said in Miami.


Floyd was expected to strengthen while continuing at the same
speed through early Thursday, moving well northeast of Puerto Rico
and the Leeward Islands in the northeastern Caribbean islands.


It was expected to be a hurricane by late Thursday.


Floyd was the sixth tropical storm of the 1999 Atlantic
hurricane season. Circular tropical weather systems are given
names when maximum winds reach 63 kph (39 mph) and become
hurricanes when top winds hit 119 kph (74 mph).

results.content:
Danielle strengthens into compact hurricane


	   MIAMI (AP) _ Halfway across the Atlantic, Tropical Storm
Danielle strengthened into a hurricane with 85-mph (136-kph) winds
and a defined eye Tuesday.
	   Compared to the ocean-hogging Hurricane Bonnie closing on the
Carolinas, Danielle is a compact storm with a pinhole eye and
hurricane-force winds extending out only 30 miles (48 kilometers).
Storm-force winds of at least 39 mph (62 kph) stretch out 80 miles
(128 kilometers).
	   But forecasters at the National Hurricane Center in Miami expect
the storm to be as strong as Bonnie in three days while still
spinning east of the U.S. Virgin Islands.
	   With a ridge building to the north, Danielle may be forced onto
a more westward course, and a hurricane watch may be posted for
Caribbean islands as early as Tuesday night.
	   At 5 p.m. EDT (2100 GMT), Danielle was located near 16.9 north
latitude and 46.2 west longitude, or about 1,030 miles (1,648
kilometers) east of the Leeward islands. Danielle is moving
west-northwest at 21 mph (34 kph).
	   Danielle is the fourth tropical storm of the Atlantic hurricane
season, which runs from June 1 to Nov. 30.
	   The Atlantic Basin typically has nine tropical storms each year,
with six of them becoming hurricanes, two of them intense. In 1997,
there were seven named storms, three hurricanes and one intense
hurricane.

results.content:
Tropical storm Celia moves away from Baja California coast


	   MEXICO CITY (AP) _ Tropical storm Celia moved away from the Baja
California coast Saturday and headed out into the Pacific,
prompting Mexican authorities to lift a tropical storm warning for
the southern part of the peninsula.
	   The storm will continue to travel out to sea and weaken, the
National Hurricane Center in Miami predicted, while noting that
``rough seas and gusty winds are likely to persist over adjacent
marine areas for the next day or two.''
	   Celia's winds weakened to about 50 mph (80 kph) by Saturday,
about 200 miles (320 kilometers) west of Cabo San Lucas, Baja
California, moving in a generally western direction at about 14 mph
(22 kph).
	   Mexico's National Meteorological Service predicted Celia may
continue to cause strong to moderate rains and heavy waves in six
Mexican Pacific coast states, and recommended boaters exercise
caution.
	   The Hurricane Center predicted the storm will stay on that track
and weaken Sunday and Monday as it moves over cooler waters. Winds
from Celia appeared to extend only about 105 miles (169 kilometers)
from the storm's center, as opposed to earlier estimates of 140
miles (225 kilometers).

results.content:
1999-05-02 
 No. 8 Cyclone Signal Hoisted in HK 


HONG KONG, May 2 (Xinhua) -- The No. 8 Signal indicating gale
or storm force winds with speeds of surpassing 62 kilometers per
hour was hoisted at 1:30 P.M., Sunday as tropical storm Leo
approached Hong Kong.


According to the latest tropical cyclone warning issued by the
Hong Kong Observatory, at 5 P.M., the center of tropical storm Leo
was estimated to be about 55 kilometers southeast of Hong Kong and
is forecast to move north-northwest at about 10 kilometers per
hour towards the eastern waters of Hong Kong.


The Home Affairs Department has opened 36 temporary shelters in
various districts for people in need of refuge during the passage
of the tropical cyclone. Some airlines have especially set up
hotlines for passengers' inquiries.


All vessels were ordered to move to typhoon shelters without
delay and residents are urged to remain indoors or seek
appropriate shelters.


Partial bus or ferry services have to be ceased.


Observatory suggested that all outdoor activities be canceled.

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-08-01 00:30 
 Tropical Storm Daniel Moving Away  


   HONOLULU (AP) -- Tropical Storm Daniel changed course away from
Hawaii as it gathered strength Monday, prompting the National
Weather Service to cancel all watches and warnings throughout the
state.


   The storm was centered about 225 miles east-northeast of
Honolulu and 150 miles east of Kahului, Maui, as of 5 p.m. HDT (11
p.m. EDT), National Weather Service forecaster Kevin Komada said.
It was moving west-northwest at about 12 mph.


   ''It's going to stay far enough away where we're not going to
anticipate any effects,'' Komada said. ''We're going to be on the
extreme outer fringe and we're not looking for winds to be that
strong.''


   After weakening overnight, the storm began intensifying Monday
with winds reaching 70 mph, just below hurricane-strength winds of
at least 74 mph.


   That strengthening caused a new center of circulation to form
north of the previous track, pulling the storm further north away
from the islands, Komada said.


   Forecasters said data from radar and hurricane-tracking planes
showed that Daniel formed an eye early Monday. Then, just as
quickly, the eye disappeared.


   ''It might briefly have become a hurricane,'' said Jim Weyman,
director of the Central Pacific Hurricane Center.


   Earlier Monday, a tropical storm warning was in effect for the
islands of Oahu, Maui, Molokai and Lanai, and a tropical storm
watch was in effect on Kauai. Those were canceled at 11 p.m. EDT.


   Maui County closed schools and county offices Monday, and state
officials told nonessential personnel to stay home. On Molokai,
officials closed the Kalaupapa National Historical Park.


   To the southeast, the storm caused few problems Sunday when it
came closest to the Big Island, Hawaii, bringing surf of up to 10
feet to east-facing beaches. Many beaches, trails and campsites
were closed.


   Farmers hoped the predicted heavy rains would bring some relief
to drought-stricken areas of the state, but forecasters said late
Monday that the most they could expect was some localized showers.


   ------


   On the Net: http://www.nws.noaa.gov/pr/hnl/index.shtml


 AP-NY-08-01-00 0030

results.content:
Forecaster: new storm in eastern Atlantic might threaten no land


	   MIAMI (AP) _ Tropical Storm Ivan formed late Sunday in the
eastern Atlantic, and forecasters said it may spend its entire life
over open water, threatening no land at all.
	   Ivan, the ninth named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season,
formed less than 600 miles west of the Cape Verde Islands, which
lie just off the northern coast of West Africa.
	   The minimal tropical storm had maximum sustained winds of 40
mph, barely surpassing the 39-mph threshold that makes a depression
a named storm. Tropical storms become hurricanes once top sustained
winds reach 74 mph.
	   ``It's a pretty ragged system. It's not very well organized,''
said Neal Dorst, a meteorologist at the National Hurricane Center
in Miami.
	   ``It's a danger only to shipping right now,'' Dorst said.
``Other than that, no one should worry too much about it
threatening them _ quite possibly ever.''
	   Ivan may never approach land because of an atmospheric weakness
to its north, Dorst said.
	   ``It's probably going to recurve out to sea, and not threaten
anyone,'' the meteorologist said.
	   At 11 p.m. EDT Sunday, Ivan was centered near 16.9 north
latitude, 34.2 west longitude, or about 580 miles west of Cape
Verde, the hurricane center reported.
	   The system was heading west-northwest near 14 mph, and was
expected to maintain that heading and speed for the next 24 hours.
	   The storm could strengthen Monday, possibly reaching top
sustained winds of 50 mph, Dorst said.

results.content:
Forecasters say Alex is barely a tropical storm


	   MIAMI (AP) _ A reconnaissance plane sent out to have a look at
Tropical Storm Alex found sustained winds near 50 mph (80 kph),
forecasters at the National Hurricane Center said.
	   At 0300 GMT Sunday, the storm was about 360 miles (580
kilometers) east of the Leeward Islands, moving west-northwest at
about 15 mph (24 kph). It was near 19 degrees 1 minute north
latitude and 57 degrees 6 minutes west longitude.
	   Meanwhile, Hurricane Estelle gained strength far off the Mexican
Pacific coast on Saturday, posing little risk to land but bringing
light rain to western Mexico.
	   The U.S. Hurricane Center in Miami said Saturday that Estelle
was located about 610 miles (980 kilometers) southwest of the tip
of the Baja California Peninsula and moving west at 15 mph (24
kph). The storm was churning maximum sustained winds of 115 mph
(185 kph), the center said.
	   Estelle was expected to continue gaining strength over the next
day or so, until it moves over cooler waters, the center said.
	   If Alex follows its course, it will be passing north of the
Leeward Islands on Sunday, with most of the showers and gusty winds
over the open Atlantic Ocean.
	   A ship in the area reported gusts of near hurricane force about
150 miles (240 kilometers) north of the storm's center.
	   Little change was expected in Alex's strength. Meanwhile, a
large tropical wave in the central tropical Atlantic Ocean was
moving westward at 15 mph (24 kph).
	   Slow development of the system was possible during the next day
or two, forecasters said.
